I don't know why this game gets such high marks, the only thing it offers is gunplay and it does this terribly. Every enemy is a bullet sponge, every gun doesn't have enough ammo to kill an enemy in a single clip, there are a million guns which is slightly less than a million more than there needs to be, many of the guns you'll find have stats like "Clip size 7, consumes 3 rounds per shot, reload speed 5 seconds." Oh wow I get to reload for 5 seconds after shooting 3 times which often isn't enough to kill a single enemy because the guns are also stupidly inaccurate. Aside from that, this is a looter shooter, so why is inventory limited to like, 8 things? Basically this is an inventory management game with an emphasis on searching loot boxes for ammo and money which features the occasional fire fight. 

Every other game with a silent protagonist who holds a gun at the bottom of the screen is better than this one.
The best of the Borderlands series. BL 3 is a waste of time.

Absolutely LOVE this game!! Has a lot of comedic parts.

I consider this game a masterpiece, flaws and all. 

Not only are the characters, story line, art style, and much more within this very detailed game extremely compelling, and in my opinion, crafted with what feels like so much passion for the game, I also find that playing this game over the years, from different consoles to 100% achievements on Steam, to the many DLCs, and still today working towards my OP levels, has not only helped me to improve my gaming, shooting, and aiming skills in other games, but has helped me have a wonderful time playing as well. This game is not easy in my opinion, there are some frustrating parts for sure, and it can feel like it is testing my patience often, but overcoming those struggles almost feels like a part of the Borderlands 2 world itself to me, in a beautiful and rewarding yet sometimes painful way! 

Borderlands 2 to me feels like a timeless classic that awakens nostalgia in many players who remember playing it their first time, and still seems to have new players wanting to try it today, which I find such a beautiful thing to see as well. 
I am so grateful to be one of these players and highly recommend it! 

If you are someone who enjoys this type of game, it is one of the greatest created of it's kind in my opinion as far as looter/shooter style story games go. 
I feel that for sure not everyone would feel the same, but I definitely consider it worth a shot if you are curious! You might just find another or a new favourite game of all time! 
Happy gaming to you and thank you for reading my review if you did!

Re-playability!!! That, pretty much, sums up the whole game. The crazy humor, the almost infinite number of guns and other gear, the main villain Handsome Jack and the many ways you can choose to play your character. These are just some of the things that I love about this game. Having been around since the game was first released, I've seen it go from promising to fantastic.

Allow this game to enter your mind, and you'll never regret it.

The game is miserable for me.

The nostalgia has been washed away, as a 12-year-old game it holds up fine, but it has been cracked open entirely. It has little value in 2024 with its adolescent humor and annoying replay mechanics. The lack of balance of classes and characters results in multiple instances where you've gotten 10 hours in and you have an "oh Fuck" moment and you have to either restart or call in friends for a 12-year-old game. It's showing deep cracks that make it difficult to recommend even at a discounted price.

I don't think I'll be finishing, which is a shame, given how much I wanted to like it but FOMO screwed it up.

This game is more fun to play with a friend than it is to play by yourself.
This isn't very fun even with someone else to suffer by your side. 

There are a lot of things in this game that straight up troll you and it's honestly really annoying than it is amusing or anything of that nature. There are many things that you have to consult the dogsh*t wiki for, fandom has gotten so bad that you can't even read half the wiki because it gets covered up by an ad you can't get rid of. There's shields that instantly down you if you take damage. There's guns that decrease your overall defense. There's enemies that if you shoot them with anything other than melee or explosives, get instantly downed if your max hp is relatively low for the class you are playing as. 

There is a lot of RNG involved for grinding for gear that quite honestly is really boring to grind for the way you're supposed to do it. There are a lot of challenges that are waiting around for a small window of time and if you miss you have to wait around some more. There are a lot of encounters that is a lot of meandering and waiting around to the point where me and my friend are doing other stuff waiting for this window of opportunity to present itself.

There are a lot of Arena based quests where if one person dies the other doesn't have much of an ability to provide cover fire from the penalty box. 
Certain arenas have a very fair sightline while others straight up disallow you from interfereing. 
There's bs one hit kills with environmental obstacles. 
There's needlessly rare and obscure collectables that are really annoying to figure out.
There's a lot of inconsistency with spawns for enemies as well as targeting priority for certain enemies.
Splash damage having inconsistent reach, pulling out calculators to figure out if the dpb for the new shotgun you found is worth the ammo cost for how much damage it deals, visual bugs that make the game harder, and other overall nonsense which seems to change what flavor of nonsense you get served up at any given moment.

There are a lot of memorable moments.
But after new game+++ this shit gets old. Even I get annoyed from picking up the voice recordings for the 258th time to annoy my friend who's tired of hearing them. Moxxie won't give me her gun half the time. The mods this community has created to streamline the gameplay has improved the game signficantly allowing us to skip cutscenes and increase our inventory storage. 

But I honestly think locking progression behind DLCs is f*cking stupid.
20 dollars for a f*ckass old game dlc. I'm not looking forward to having to make new characters to get the character specific acheivements. 
F*ckass game tbh.

Borderlands 2 is an absolute blast, whether you're flying solo or teaming up with friends. It's hailed as the pinnacle of looter shooters for good reason. My tip? Take your time on the first playthrough. The game is brimming with crucial story dialogues that unveil the narrative's depth. Miss them, and you risk missing out on the game's essence. Yet, fear not if you prefer a casual approach; you can still enjoy the gameplay, albeit with a foggy understanding of the missions' context.

Replayability is where Borderlands 2 shines brightest. With its wealth of side quests, exhilarating boss battles, and expansive areas to explore, there's always something new to discover. The gunplay is impeccable, and while the vast array of weapons might seem daunting initially, mastering their nuances becomes second nature with practice.

The game's DLCs are a treasure trove of content, with each offering a substantial extension to the main storyline. From sprawling expansions that add hours to your playtime to bite-sized headhunters packed with secrets and unique weapons, there's no shortage of fresh experiences to dive into.

What's more, Borderlands 2 runs smoothly on even modest hardware, making it accessible to a wide audience. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its enduring appeal, with fans still creating videos, mods, and other content to this day. Trust me, this is one game you don't want to miss out on. Give it a shot‚Äîyou won't be disappointed.

Actually unplayable.

There is an issue with the game starting in offline and going online causing the game to get stuck in an endless loop trying to connect to the servers that has been around ever since they did their thing with Epic like 4 years ago. Has yet to be fixed. 
While the person at 2k customer support who I was talking with was very nice, I highly doubt anything is gonna be done about this considering its been around for so long and countless reddit threads, steam discussions and possibly bug reports exist about it.

Worst thing about all this is that this only affects *some* people. So the game working is completely up to chance, Its like they finally figured out that the gambling aspect from loot drops is the most fun thing about this game so they made it so that you can gamble before even playing. 

Is it gonna work? Is it gonna be unplayable? Who can possibly know for certain? Only way to find out is to buy the game.

John F. Kennedy: For time and the world do not stand still. Change is the law of life. And those who only look into the past or the present are certain to miss the future.

The screen transitions to showing Kennedy in black and white, sitting at a table with Fidel Castro.

John F. Kennedy: I said, 'are certain to miss the future'!

Fidel Castro: [laughs] Co√±o... I missed that.

Robert McNamara walks into the room towards Castro.

Robert McNamara: Prime Minister Castro, this missile crisis was the last straw. We almost blew ourselves up. Now we invited you here today...

John F. Kennedy: In good faith!

Robert McNamara: ... in good faith, to sort this thing out.

Robert walks back towards John F. Kennedy.

Fidel Castro: (nae naeing on the table) And why is he here? He lost!

Nixon is shown sitting left of them at the table, annoyed at Castro's remark.

John F. Kennedy: As I always say, forgive your enemies, but remember their names. Now gentlemen, as I like to think, in the long history of the world, that there are only a few generations...

Noises are heard in the background.

Richard Nixon: (looking frantic and ducking) Sounds like someone breaking in...

John F. Kennedy: Just the storm, Dick. Sit down.

Zombies appear smashing a window on the other side of it, making noises and breaking through.

Richard Nixon: Oh my God!

Robert McNamara: It appears the Pentagon has been breached.

John F. Kennedy: Zombies. Gentlemen, at times like these our capacity to retaliate must be and has to be massive, to deter all forms of aggression.

Kennedy walks over to the wall behind him and hits a button, which makes the wall flip around to show an armory of weapons.

John F. Kennedy: Gentlemen, lock and load!

The screen turns black.

Fidel Castro: Viva la Revolution.

Screen then shows the four of them coming out of the armory. (Left to right) McNamara with a Stakeout with Grip, Kennedy with a China Lake, Castro with a Bowie Knife and a Python and Nixon with two HS-10s.

Robert McNamera: Any last words, Mr. President?

Richard Nixon: Yes Jack, any superlative words of inspiration for our humble troops?

John F. Kennedy: Do not pray for easy lives, my friends. Pray to be stronger men.

The group cocks their guns as the screen fades into color, and then the intro ends.

Probably the peak of FPS games ever. Great cast, story, locations, combat. Despite TVH and UVHM being literally the same playthrough just harder I've still gone through this game countless times. Most of the dlcs feel kind of boring but Fight for Sanctuary gives you Hot Mama Sniper and NO I DON'T CARE IF THE ENEMY RESISTS FIRE I WILL STILL USE HER
BUY IT NOW!

There are very few perfect games out there, this is one of them. An action packed laugh fest with amazing characters, a perfect villain, heartbreaking moments, and guns! Guns! AND MORE GUNS! 4 main character classes with skill trees to match your playstyle, (two more if you buy the DLC yes every DLC is worth it). It's fun alone, but even better with friends. Heck get the whole crew with up to 4 players. Smash, Slice, Shoot, and Loot your way across the wild amazing planet of ~Pandora~. Home to an assortment of crazy creatures, endless baddies, robots, and don't forget everyone's favorite Psychos <3. 

While my Steam time might say 70.5 hours, let me assure you, I've spent far longer in the Borderlands. Owning this game on almost every platform. Easily dumping hours beyond count into this amazing game. And if the base game ain't enough for ya and you crave more Borderlands, get the DLC's every one is packed with hours of content and exciting new things to explore. Personal favorites being Assault on Dragon Keep and Commander Lilith's Fight for Sanctuary. 

Borderlands 2 gets tuned up to 11/10 for me cause this game is a masterpiece and should easily be in anyone's collection. I couldn't recommend this game enough. 

Good luck out there Vault Hunters, and may Fortunes Favor smile on you.~

Game is a lousy port that can't run at max settings with RTX graphics cards due to a programming error "not enough visual memory".... which is preposterous given that i'm mainly playing it with a 3090 (24gb VRAM). I've had to essentially turn down everything except for resolution and texture quality, and even then I can't enter certain areas like "The Caustic Caverns" because the game crashes when I look at certain scenery. It gets worse when you do new game + and the added effect bonuses from developed skill trees stress the graphics even more.

10/10 Game Good DLC will play again

Played for a little bit. Pretty fun with friends, but can get a little stale after the 500 hour mark

Edit: I played for another 280-ish hours, I have been playing this game over multiple consoles and I am now going to give a nostalgia fueled biased review.
This is the best Looter shooter game you're going to get, in my opinion ever. The sheer amount of Depth and Replay-ability in the game makes it worth any amount of money, Handsome Jack is an incredibly well written and charismatic antagonist and CARRIES any conversation or scene he's in. The gun-play, unique gun rolls, and action skill trees allow for tons of replay value and unique builds.

I will pay Gearbox thousands of dollars to never bring Handsome Jack back every again, 10/10.
love it

This is without a shadow of a doubt THE BEST looter shooter you're ever gonna find as well as one of the best FPS games of all time, and it only gets better with age.

 It really has it all; 
- Super engaging gameplay loop, the skill trees give you tons of freedom with how you wanna play
- Actual good story and writing (which cannot be said for it's younger brother Borderlands 3)
- Fantastic art style and awesome music 
- Very diverse sets of locations each one more unique then the last one. One moment you're walking around a bunch of icebergs and then the next you're gunning down bandits in a wild west type of town.


Forget Borderlands 3 or Destiny THIS is how you do a kickass lootershooter.

Well, Borderland 2 is one of my most-played games in Steam. Got it back in 2016 when I built my first PC. Even though I'm an XCOM/Darkest Dungen type of gamer I enjoyed my time playing this game. The gameplay the endless amount of guns the music and the atmosphere. but what sticks out about this game is the writing and characters and it has one of the best villains in gaming I was surprised by how much profanity in this game. This game is so good that I didn't have the urge to check out the next game because they have outdone themselves in this one I knew it was kinda impossible to top it and I was right. If you want to play a funny shorter exploration with a decent story-type game this is it. it's worth checking in 2023 even if you play it solo.

The second game of the Borderland Saga is the one with better graphics an ideas, a more solid presentation than his older brother. Sadly, this is where the overall experience stops improving: something that I was able to praise from Borderlands 1 was his gun play, where every weapon or build was useful and rewarding, sadly, on Borderlands 2 this is not the case, the overall movement and gun-play is more grounded than previously, and for me it feels way slower/boring than the first entry, making it harder to continue if you are not attracted to the rest of the game (story, style, power content, etc), which is once again, better than the first game in general.

The second wasteland it's fine, just less fun than the first.

Final Note: 7/10

As a steam deck user whom docks the deck.  There is a glaring issue with the game using multiple screens. While playing the game of borderlands 2 the game itself randomly swaps away from the screen your game is on to any other content that is open. For example say you have chrome open running music or what ever in the background. While playing the game, you end up losing control of your character not able to press buttons. This conflict is constant and the steam system struggles with it.

For series newcomers: I love this game; it's the video game equivalent of a summer popcorn movie. The gameplay is fast-paced, punchy, and challenging without being punishing. Generally it plays just as well in single-player as in multiplayer; some character specialties are clearly more suited for multiplayer, but you can always choose a different skillset that works better for playing alone. The only downside is that the writing feels incredibly dated. It's a competent story with generally good dialogue, but it's a very 2010 kind of game - lots of "quirkiness" in that lolrandom style that feels a bit cringeworthy now. The main villain is the kind of sarcastic quippy jerk that felt really fresh when the game came out and has been done way beyond death by now.

For BL fans: This is the best game in the series. It's a little bit better in every way than 1, and it's basically the same gameplay as 3 and the Pre-Sequel without being as self-referential or self-impressed.

[h1] This game is a 9/10 [/h1]

[h1] TOO LONG, DIDN'T READ [/h1]
[b]BUY THE GAME WHEN IT IS ON SALE! IT'S WORTH IT![/b]
You are a character hunting a vault (Hence the name, Vault Hunter). However, there is an antagonist named Handsome Jack and he wants to kill you and have the vault for himself. You tried stopping him in a train but you've been tricked with explosives and the whole train blows up, leaving you unconscious. [b]No more explaining the story.[/b]

When playing the game, the main purpose is to shoot enemies and loot weapons, ammo, health, and shields. There are almost a million weapons to choose from but they all have level requirements. The more you play the game, the higher your level will be. Making your character stronger and being able to use higher leveled weapons. There is a thing called a Skill Tree and it is really important for you. The story is amazing and once you beaten the game, you can always replay it with higher difficulties each time you beat the game. Your character level will not reset when playing higher difficulties. If you pick a another character, then it will reset your levels.

[h2] Price: 8/10 [/h2]
The game itself costs $19.99 USD. If you wanna save money, just get it when it's on sale. The DLCs are AMAZING and you MUST to get them if you want to level up more. You can get them from the season pass or buying a bundle. Buy it when it is on sale, you will not regret it.

[h2] Gameplay: 10/10 [/h2]
Borderlands 2 is a shoot and loot First Person Shooter game. You can choose different characters that has unique abilities when playing them. The more you play the game, the higher your character level will be. Making you stronger and unlocking stronger weapons. There are Rifles, SMGs, LMGs, Shotguns, Pistols, Snipers, and of course Rocket Launchers. Borderlands 2 have 6 colored weapons. Ranging from:

[h3]White = Common[/h3]
[h3]Green = Uncommon[/h3]
[h3]Blue = Rare[/h3]
[h3]Purple = Epic[/h3]
[h3]Orange = Legendary[/h3]
[h3]Pink = Eridium-Technology (E-Tech)[/h3]

[h2] What is E-Tech?[/h2]
According to the Borderlands Fandom Wiki, "[i]E-tech weapons, or Eridium technology weapons, are a type of experimental weapon. They usually use multiple rounds of ammunition per shot. They have low projectile velocity, cannot score critical hits, has high damage and elemental effect chance.[/i]" Are E-Tech weapons better than legendary weapons? Not really. A level 50 E-Tech weapon can be better than a level 30 Legendary weapon. It really depends on the weapon type, damage, and level requirement.

There's are also shields in the game. All shields have different abilities but most of them can be understandable if you read the description of it.

And last but not least, there are elemental effects. Effects like Shock, Fire, Slag, Corrosive, and Explosive. I'm not gonna explain it because an NPC named Marcus will teach you how they work in the game.

OH, I FORGOT ABOUT THE SKILL TREE! OOPS!
[h2]Skill Tree[/h2]
The skill tree is a [b]NECESSITY[/b] in Borderlands 2. Each character has different skills and can be spent however you like. You need to play the game a lot in order for you to have more skill points. If you want to have the best setup for your character, just watch YouTube videos for your specific character.

[h2] Lore: 10/10 [/h2]
The lore is straight forward. You are character hunting a vault (Hence the name, Vault Hunter). Your plan is to stop an antagonist named Handsome Jack from unlocking the vault. You tried finding him in his train but you've been tricked with explosives and the whole train blows up, leaving you unconscious. When gaining consciousness, you'll meet ClapTrap/CL4P-TP (Warning: ClapTrap is annoying). I don't want to explain the whole story to you because I'll spoil it. It's best to play the game and learn for yourself. Or, you can watch a whole YouTube video about it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_wvb8jAKsno

[h2] Graphic: 7/10 [/h2]
This game is old and it has good graphics. There's literally no further explanation for the graphics, it's good.

[h2] PC Requirements: 9/10 [/h2]
Not only can you play Borderlands 2 on Windows. [b]You can play the game on Mac and Linux[/b] You don't need the latest GPU and CPU for this game. You can probably run Borderlands 2 on a medium budget pc and have medium or high video settings. 

[h2] Entertainment: 10/10 [/h2]
Borderlands 2 is a REALLY FUN GAME! You can replay the game so many times, the DLCs are amazing to play, each character is fun to play, and you can invite 3 of your friends to join you! You might get tired and bored from playing the game a lot by yourself. But with friends, it will probably be an amazing or chaotic experience to have.

[h2] Is it worth it?: YES IT IS [/h2]
BORDERLANDS 2 IS WORTH BUYING. IF YOU REGRET BUYING THE GAME, YOU'RE WRONG! YOU CAN'T REGRET BUYING BORDERLANDS 2. NEVER! Overall, it's a great game.

While this game "fixes" some of the issues I had with the first one, it brings about its own slew of issues that make it barely playable - but hey! - at least it's playable, unlike BL1.
Let me go through some of the things that I actually do like:
-The Quest system has been tweaked slightly for quality of life. Some quests you can turn in immediately after completion by bringing up the Quest Log. For the ones you have to turn-in manually, Sanctuary is usually the place to go - so there's a central hub that's not too large for you to do a mass completion lap. Not the best... Still would rather be able to turn in all completed quests from the Log itself, but whatever. It's an improvement.
-Speaking of improvements, gotta give credit where credit is due - the Enemies! Enemy A.I. has been overhauled in this game. They're smarter, use their weapons more effectively, and actually move and dodge your attacks when you ADS or shoot at them. A much needed upgrade from "stand still and get shot in head". That's about it. I appreciate the A.I. tweak. Thank you.
Aaaand the bad stuff - the game itself. Core gameplay is still terrible - offering zero replay-ability. You can't skip dialogue you have no intention of hearing, you can't skip cutscenes, and while the most of the game is fairly linear with a central hub it still takes forever to get to places with areas being blocked off by invisible walls, jump physics being somehow worse now than BL1 and Halo 1 combined, and map layout generally being awful forcing you to slog your way through a snake-like path to get where you want to go.
The main antagonist, Handsome Jack, is not likable, funny, or a third redeeming quality. He's annoying, stupid, and talks too much. This does not make me want to hunt him down and defeat him because he's evil, it makes we want to kill him so I can get the game over with faster and so he'll shut the hell up. I like seeing the protagonists from BL1 come into play, but hot frickin' damn are they a bunch of annoying mentally challenged warts on the ugly ass of Pandora. Their personalities are so badly written it makes marvel characters seem likable. Shooting feels a little better, but the guns suck now. ARs are completely ruined with half of them being trash and the other half unusable. SMGs are still the God tier guns like in every game. Enemy balance is back and forth. Your level (like BL1) is way too dependent on difficulty. If you're one level below, you deal 90% less damage, but if you level up one level higher, you OHKO everything with a sniper headshot. It's disgustingly bad game design like this that makes me wonder if their QA team spoke English.
Anyway, TL;DR - Game is bad but slightly better than the first. 2/10. Don't play this unless you hate yourself.

This game is a lot of fun. The menus and interfaces feel painfully ported in from a console, but you get used to it. The gameplay is fun, the dialogue is humorous. Sometimes it's kind of annoying to complete quests and figure out where things are because the map system is kind of terrible. For example if your objective is in another area, the objective marker is dropped at the location to the exit to your current location. Hard to explain but yeah the map system is just kind of trash which makes it cumbersome to navigate. It only lets you see one quest at a time so you can't really plan out an effective route, you just kinda go. You might be in an area where quest objectives are for a different quest, but because it's not "selected", you don't even see them on your map.

Once you get past all of that, this game is a ton of fun and the DLCs make it definitely worth it to buy the GOTY edition. The combat is pretty fun because of all the different weapon types.

I play this game EXCLUSIVELY in SINGLE PLAYER. People will tell you that it is much more fun playing with friends, and truly it can be, but don't disregard this game as a single player game. It is insanely addictive, and it actually poses some slight challenges to you to play it solo. Beating Raid Bosses solo is actually a genuine accomplishment, if you can actually do it. They are meant to be beaten witha 4 player team, but you CAN beat many of them solo. The new Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode (UVHM) makes it an even more insane challenge to play solo just for the regular game enemies. Needing to pump them full of slag just so you can actually get ready to start damaging them with any real power. Of course all this is basically a math problem of damage output vs. damage defense.

Borderlands 2, simply put, is one of the best games ever made in my opinion. The sheer addictiveness and fun in playing it are jsut off the charts. I recommend this to anyone, even if you think you won't like it. I don't see myself stopping BL2 anytime soon.

Just noticed, that when I was writting reviews to all BL games, I've missed the most played one.

Well, gunplay is interesting, after completing the story there available hundreds of hours of grind, story itself is interesting and Jack is one of the best villains in games - both charismatic and furyprovoking, many DLC's, part of which have fun stories (Tiny Tuna's is really good one, for example).

If you do not care about story and only care about gameplay - better chose BL3 or BL:The Pre-Sequel, thought this one still holds the test of time.
If you care about story - skip BL3 like it never existed and play TPS and BL2 (and check best rated DLC's to them).

Game is played like classic Diablo, btw - at first you run through first difficulty, then at second and most fun and unlocks are on third (but need to buy Ultimate Vault Hunter DLC, its cheap).
Difficulty spike here is bad - in BL3 or TPS is better. First difficulty is somewhat challenging, as you lack unlocks and legendaries, second difficulty is cake walk and everyone is too easy (with some elite mobs being bullet sponges for no reason), and then on third difficulty challenge is again pretty good one. OP levels balanced poorly too, because after around OP5 - everything oneshots, so you need shield and health regen (health to get the "can't be oneshoted if 51+% hp hidden mechanics, so you have 2 hits before dying and not 1), but if you like risky style of play - it is fun (I am on OP10).

Multiplayer is also fun to play, especially if someone will take Maya as healer/resurector (still not the Chaos Claptrap in TPS creates during healing) and others go different classes too.

Also, IMPORTANT: buy game only as part of Handsome Collection or Pandora's Box, or you will not get a bunch of content (previously it was sold separately, now it sold only as part of those collections). Collections often have huge discounts and they include all games with all DLC's of franchise. Sometimes price is as low as 10-15$ for everything.

Borderlands 2!

[i]A classic[/i]. One of the best games of its decade, a perfect sequel and the best game in a looter-shooter genre.

Being 11+ years old, Borderlands 2 holds up very well for simple reasons ‚Äî timeless visual style, fantastic writing and carefully crafted gameplay loop. The story by itself never gets old... But there are also at least 4 classes to play, tons of missions, locations, characters, and hundreds of weapons. With all DLCs there is enough content to play for 200+ hours.

Compared to Borderlands 1, developers improved every aspect and multiplied all the best parts of the original game by ten. Variety of loot is immeasurable and characters have many playstyles and skills. The world of Borderlands is not just empty deserts now, and even those were brought to life ‚Äî every bandit camp has small story, secret chest or just some fun detail from bandit life. The lore about Eridians, Vaults and greedy corporations really starts to shine here (and peaks in Borderlands 3). And all of that expanded even more in great DLCs (one of which became its own franchise as Tiny Tina's Wonderlands).

Definitely recommended at least to try for every gamer.

*Warning: spoilers* 

Great sequel to an amazing game.

I loved Borderlands 2 and had a great time with this amazing sequel. The humor, silly atmosphere and new features created a fresh new experience for me.

In Borderlands 2, the story continues from the first game. There is a new vault, discovered by our main villain, Handsome Jack. You start as one of the four new Vault Hunters, employed by Handsome Jack himself. Like the bastard he is, he betrays you and blows up the train you are traveling on, leaving you for dead. You are found by Claptrap, who takes you to safety. You travel to Sanctuary, a protected city with bandits, ex-Crimson Raiders and other adventures, who resist Handsome Jack's monopoly and power of the planet Pandora.

You learn that the new Vault Key is being transported via train and you, your buddies Roland, Mordecai, Brick and Lilith (from the first game) make plans to intercept and raid the train. You stop the train but instead of the Vault key, a big ass robot comes out and ambushes you. You defeat him and eventually discover that Angel (the entity that guided you through the first game) is a Siren and actually Jack‚Äôs daughter. He is using her Siren powers to charge up the Vault Key. She begs you to end her existence to stop Jack and after an successful attack on Jack‚Äôs main facility, you grant her wish, ending her life support. Handsome Jack is furious and launches a full scale assault on Sanctuary, almost destroying it. Lilith uses her bling bling witch Siren powers to teleport the whole freaking city to a different location, saving the day. Lilith is captured however, and Jack is using her instead of Angel to charge up the Vault Key.

The Vault Hunters eventually learn the location of the new vault and prepare to stop Jack, who is already close upon opening it. They fight their way there, confront Handsome Jack and defeat him. They fail to prevent the Vault from being opened and the Vault Warrior is unleashed. In this final fight, the Vault Hunters make short work of him, saving the planet. The game ends with a cliffhanger, revealing multiple other Vaults in the galaxy as shown by Lilith in the aftermath with Jack. This created the opportunity for multiple other sequels and/or prequels.

I really liked Handsome Jack. He is one of the best villains that I encountered in a videogame. His personality, voice acting, dark humor and overall presentation is just perfect. His comments, actions and threats to your characters were hilarious and I laughed more than I ever thought possible.

The graphics are upgraded from the previous game and are still in the Cell Shading format. For Borderlands games, this works perfectly and gives the game its charm. The animations and effects are a lot better compared to the first game and I think this game had some more color and depth in it.

In terms of sound, Borderlands 2 improved greatly from its predecessor. The sound effects are spot on and the new dubstep soundtracks are great. But the best improvement is the voice acting. It is funny, crystal clear and overall, I can only praise it.

The movement, controls and mechanics are improved with various GUI tweaks, better menus and improved control of inventory management. The mechanics work fluently and in terms of gunplay, I have nothing to complain. It is fast paced, accurate and overall, just great.

Borderlands 2 also introduced a million new weapons, new brands, new types of guns and a lot more variation in enemies and biomes. Classic weapons and enemies are also present like Skags and Rakks, which all have more variants now.

I still think the best part of this game is the humor. Every mission, every encounter, everything is one big joke. Names of bosses, many times, refer to pop culture icons and certain missions are just hilarious and stupid. It is just as good (if not better) than the first Borderlands game.

The only big downside with Borderlands 2, is the introduction of loot boxes, in which you need to buy Golden Keys, so you can use your hard earned, real life money to get a chance of a legendary gun, giving you an paid edge over other players in case of duels. Borderlands 2 is a product of its time, in which this ‚Äúgenius‚Äù idea was introduced in many games, including Shadow of Mordor, Star Wars Battlefront and many more.

Another small issue, for me at least, is the ridiculous amount of DLC that the game offers. It is almost as bad as The Sims. DLC on it‚Äôs own is not bad, and the DLC campaigns where all fun to play, but besides extra missions and campaigns, millions of skins, Upgrade pack 1, Upgrade Pack 2, soundtracks, animations, unorganized bundles of diverse skins and content (but not all), and Season Passes are added, and it is a complete mess. I never had/have the feeling that I could experience the full game because ‚ÄúI am always missing something‚Äù. I also completely lost the chronological order of DLC, what is playable content and what is just a soundtrack or a new skin.

Lastly, some boss encounters are ridiculously hard. So hard in fact, that you can only complete them with friends or random people. I did not like the ‚Äúforced co-op‚Äù aspect of the game in which you can get stuck on your progress (mainly raid bosses) because you do not have the friends or people to complete it.

In the end, the main game was a lot of fun and my completed DLC‚Äôs so far, were enjoyable enough.

Purely based on the main game alone, I would definitely recommend this awesome game.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

[h1]Borderlands 2: A Looter-Shooter Extravaganza of Mayhem and Humor[/h1]

[quote=author]Gear up, Vault Hunter! Welcome to the pandemonium of Pandora in Borderlands 2. Developed by Gearbox Software, this irreverent looter-shooter takes you on a wild ride through a vibrant and chaotic world filled with humor, mayhem, and an arsenal of bazillion guns. Are you ready to embark on a quest for riches and glory in the Borderlands?[/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Borderlands 2 is the epitome of the looter-shooter genre, seamlessly blending fast-paced gameplay with a hilarious narrative set against the backdrop of the chaotic world of Pandora. Whether you're a lone wolf or part of a ragtag team of Vault Hunters, prepare for an unforgettable adventure filled with over-the-top characters and unforgettable moments.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Unique Visual Style[/h2]
Borderlands 2's distinctive art style, combining cel-shading with a gritty aesthetic, sets it apart from other games. The vibrant colors, bold outlines, and comic book-inspired visuals create a world that is both visually striking and instantly recognizable. Pandora is a canvas of chaos, waiting for you to leave your mark.
[hr][/hr]

[h2]Dynamic Characters and Narrative[/h2]
Borderlands 2 introduces a memorable cast of characters, each with their own quirks and personalities. From the enigmatic Handsome Jack to the lovable robot Claptrap, the game's narrative unfolds through witty dialogue and unexpected twists. The humor-infused storytelling keeps players engaged from the first shot to the final boss battle.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Loot Galore: Bazillion Guns[/h2]
If variety is the spice of life, then Borderlands 2 is an explosive banquet. The game boasts a staggering number of guns‚Äîliterally, a bazillion. From conventional firearms to outlandish rocket launchers and guns that talk, each playthrough promises new and absurd weaponry. The loot system ensures that every battle could yield your next favorite gun.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Cooperative Gameplay[/h2]
Borderlands 2 is a social experience at its core. Team up with friends or other players online to form a squad of Vault Hunters. Cooperative gameplay introduces synergies between character classes, creating chaotic yet strategic battles. The camaraderie of shared loot and collective triumphs adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the mayhem.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Expansive World and Side Quests[/h2]
Pandora is a vast and diverse world, filled with deserts, frozen tundras, and sprawling cities. Borderlands 2 encourages exploration through a multitude of side quests that offer both unique challenges and hilarious anecdotes. From bounty hunting to solving quirky problems. [spoiler] Pandora is a sandbox of adventures waiting to be discovered.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Skill Trees and Character Customization[/h2]
Tailor your Vault Hunter to your preferred playstyle with Borderlands 2's extensive skill trees. Whether you're a gunslinger, a master of stealth, or a force of elemental destruction, the skill system allows for deep character customization. Experiment with different builds to find the perfect combination for your chaotic journey.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]DLC Expansions and Season Pass[/h2]
[spoiler]Gearbox Software continues to expand the Borderlands 2 universe with DLC expansions that offer new campaigns, characters, and challenges. The Season Pass provides access to a treasure trove of additional content, ensuring that your adventure in Pandora can continue with fresh experiences and loot to discover.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Timeless Soundtrack and Audio Design[/h2]
Borderlands 2 is not just a visual spectacle; it's a symphony of chaos and humor. The game's soundtrack, featuring a mix of adrenaline-pumping tunes and quirky compositions, enhances the overall atmosphere. From the slapstick humor to the booming explosions, the audio design contributes to the game's signature immersive experience.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Borderlands 2 is a tour de force in the looter-shooter genre, delivering a perfect blend of humor, mayhem, and addictive gameplay. With its unforgettable characters, endless loot possibilities, and a world that begs to be explored, Borderlands 2 remains a timeless classic that continues to draw players back into the pandemonium of Pandora.

[quote=author]Get ready to loot, shoot, and laugh your way through the pandemonium of Pandora - where the guns are plentiful, the humor is abundant, and the mayhem is positively infectious![/quote]

I know it's been long, and this is probably very old news, but here's my two cents on Borderlands 2. Absolutely fantastic story, brilliant characters, great dialogues, amazing humour, and a killer musical score. The attention to detail is mind-blowing, especially considering the massive amount of content. Some DLCs are hardly "DLCs", more like whole games on their own right. Gameplay can become repetitive, especially if farming for equipment isn't your thing, but even so, the game allows you to play it at your own pace most of the time, which I find to be the ace up its sleeve. This is not to say there is no challenge, but sometimes you want to bring mayhem while others you just want to fire it up just so you can enjoy its vistas and chill. Did I mention great atmosphere too? Even though it's not open world, some maps are big enough to titilate the explorer type players. Not to mention the countless challenges, some of which do need some serious effort to be put in exploration. Also, even with it being a tad repetitive at times as I mentioned, it still keeps your interest as your character progresses too, turning gradually into a one man army. I've been playing mostly Slavador, the damage in high levels is insane, especially with the right combination of skills and gear. I guess it's similar for most characters, if not all. One thing that has struck me is that when you max out, the game has a strange feeling, since you don't need to either collect money or kill for XP. Even so it doesn't lose its interest and it continues to be fun as hell. Overall it's the game I've played the most in at least a decade, maybe in my life. 11/10, seriously. It's great when the team knows what they're doing and are in the mood for making something extraordinary.

Borderlands 2 is a first-person shooter game that has received positive reviews from critics and gamers alike. The game was developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K Games in 2012. The game‚Äôs story takes place on the planet Pandora, where the player assumes the role of a Vault Hunter who is on a mission to find a new vault and defeat the villainous Handsome Jack.

According to IGN, Borderlands 2 is an ‚Äúoverall superior game‚Äù that improves on almost every major game system from its predecessor. The game‚Äôs hook is the loot, which includes guns, ammo, character skins, grenade mods, and class mods. The hunt for loot becomes intoxicating because of the tiny rush you get each time a rare colored item spills out of a chest or is dropped by a recently slain enemy. Every firefight and intense boss battle becomes all the more rewarding, because, though you might die a few times and want to crush something near you in real life, it suddenly feels like everything is going to be OK when you‚Äôre blasting away enemies with a newly looted gun.

Common Sense Media also praised the game for its fast and frenetic gameplay, unique visuals, and multiple modes (drop-in/drop-out, side-by-side, or online co-op). The sequel offers many more missions and challenges than its predecessor, exceptional writing, and memorable characters and enemies.

Overall, Borderlands 2 is a fun and engaging game that is worth playing. It has a great story, excellent gameplay mechanics, and a ton of replay value. If you‚Äôre a fan of first-person shooters or action RPGs, then you should definitely give Borderlands 2 a try!

I'm simply a sick puppy, and despite my years of Diablo 2 and other addictive action RPG's that I played- I never got into world of warcraft once over all that time.  However, I already know for sure that I will dump several hundred (potentially less if the story starts to get kind of aimless or boring) in Borderlands 2, when I've never even touched another game in the franchise.  In fact I've heard anything but terrible things about Borderlands for years, the original game was kind of mediocre looking and I didn't see the appeal at all.  Nowadays most people are familiar with "looter shooters" as in its pretending to be a first-person shooter, but its really an EXP grinder with magical, colorful and elemental damage imbued weapons to traipse over endlessly till you're blue in the face or dead, likely from not eating in the past week as you tirelessly play Borderlands 2.  

I'm not saying its bad, its got the formula down pat, but everything else so far has been pretty below my usual bar.  Loads of glitches, getting stuck in walls, accidentally jumping into things that get me stuck in a wall, a stupid progression system that insta-respawns enemies if its in a quest related area, and oh yeah how could I forget- its Diablo 2.  Yes, I love Diablo 2.   Thanks Gearbox, but that doesn't mean I thought Diablo 2 needed a comic relief character every few minutes to remind me I'm alive and playing a videogame.  The writing is pretty terrible, not so unfathomably terrible that you can't laugh at it, but you usually are laughing because you realize someone actually got paid to write some of the lines that genuinly superb voice actors ended up delivering.  Other things are just themes, or characters or stuff that I have no reference point for since I never played the original.

So is Clap trap supposed to be funny?  Is he our gateway in the "Border-verse" if you will?  Because he's all over the original title, but strangely after the tutorial area he is relegated to quest giver character.  So what is the point of him being in every title then?  The humor just doesn't appeal to me, and I'm not fond of any of the characters that I've met throughout my couple of playthroughs.  Handsome Jack is irritatingly smug, and you'd think it would give you some motivation to go after that antagonist, but instead its like the opposite where you just want to mute his voice most of the time he pops up on your radio.  I've restarted a couple of times once I got more of the mechanics down and honestly I don't know how people can play this on a loop without getting bored of that first 2 hours or so.  I would say that a lot of that early game is tedious, where unless you know exactly what you're doing, then you'll need to do all these side-quests that usually involve going to location A or B and killing everything there.  I'm not even sure how unique this type of Action RPG gameplay was for 2010-2012-ish.

The DLC is highway robbery, and I feel like I keep getting ripped off.  I bought the original game on sale, but it strangely hid the "more dlc bundle for a couple more bucks" from me until I accidentally clicked on an in-game menu that actually took me to the store page for that particular DLC.  What a joke and kind of insulting that they think I'll spend money for a couple of crappy missions or some cosmetic changes to my characters that I can't even see while playing unless I'm in a menu.  The interface is also disgustingly infected with some kind of horrid console-itis disease.  Its truly not a great interface, nor is it intuitive to go into a separate menu to give my character "bad ass" points for random things like extra damage or extra health, or better accuracy when everything is gear-based to begin with.  Those lists of things that give you more points just go on and on.  Some people have joked that this game was literally designed for addicts, but I'm sort of inclined to agree at this point.  I feel like I lost money on this product, but also I just wasn't really that familiar with the series so far.   Oh well another steam sale regret.

i originally bought this game on the Xbox 360, then Xbox one and now on steam as well. i feel justified in every purchase i made. i have over 7000 hours on all platforms, with over 150 playthroughs (of what i can recall) and met some of the greatest friends i have. and so here is a proper review for anyone willing to buy this. 

a true front runner in the looter shooter genre, borderlands 2 revolutionizes the genre with interesting classes, fun and unique gear, impeccable side content and one of the most i interesting villains in modern gaming. the main campaign is a fun rider, never taking itself too seriously unless it matters. the soundtrack is outstanding, with the wind-shear waste background music still being something i listen to now. the DLCs are hit and miss, however the Tiny Tinas DLC being one of if not the greatest piece of borderlands content to date. i recommended this to everyone i can, as it is truly a sight to behold. 

i would totally advise anyone who has this to play through at least the normal mode with every character to enjoy all styles of playing the game has to offer, and to buy all content Borderlands 2 has as it really enhances the experience. and for those who like to mod, this game has a fascinating modding community and a welfare of enjoyable content creators like Joltzdude and K6 just to name the popular ones :)

Borderlands 2 takes everything great about the original and amplifies it to a whole new level. The game's signature blend of fast-paced shooting, RPG depth, and a brilliantly crafted open world is a pure adrenaline rush. The diverse environments, each teeming with personality, coupled with the offbeat humor and unforgettable characters, create an immersive experience. The expanded arsenal of weapons and the refined skill trees add depth and replayability, keeping the action fresh and exciting. Whether playing solo or with friends, Borderlands 2 is a wild ride that delivers non-stop fun and an addictively satisfying loot-hunting experience.

Pray, indulge me, for I must declare that Borderlands, in all its splendid glory, doth hold the position of mine most cherished video game franchise hitherto. Why, you may ask? Oh, 'tis the EXPLOSIONS, my dear friend, as proclaimed by the esteemed Mr. Torgue! But, verily, one wonders what else doth captivate the soul within this digital realm. Could it be the bewitching allure of the cell-shaded art style, so pleasing to the eye? Or perchance the astounding abundance of over a 'Bazillion' guns, the likes of which doth leave one's head spinning in delight? Ah, who truly knows, who can fathom the depths of such enchantment? 

Amongst the series, Borderlands 2 reigns paramount in my heart, and the valiant Gaige, the fairest of Vault hunters, holds a special place therein. It doth earn a perfect score of ten out of ten, and I doth wholeheartedly recommend it to all seeking a jolly campaign to embark upon, be it in solitude or accompanied by dear comrades!

Gearbox and 2K are horrific developers/publishers and they seem to take pleasure in extorting their most loyal fans. [b]They will spit on you and expect you to thank them for the water.[/b] The Ultimate Vault hunter DLC is meant to give you access to the raid on digistruct peak and OP levels once you hit 72, but after they randomly increased the level cap to 80 and placed this behind a 15 dollar paywall, you now need to pay an extortionate amount of money to play a part of the game that you already bought. This should genuinely be illegal. I don't know how they are allowed to just take something away from players and force them to pay more money like that. 
[list]

[*]They do not care about the quality of their games.

[*]They want to bleed you dry.

Borderlands 2 is the quintessential looter shooter, redefined the entire game archetype, and promptly managed to outdo EVERY other title, including its predecessor and its future installments, in one fell swoop. The core gameplay is extremely solid and the skill trees manage to differentiate most of the characters enough to make you focus on one core weapon/manufacturer type - Maya and Gaige being the only two who that doesn't really apply to - and the enemies are pretty reasonable all things considered. RPG Loaders excluded.

If my play hours aren't enough of an indication, I am in love with BL2. I've gotten two characters (Gaige and Maya) to UVHM, am working on every other character, and then intend on clearing UVHM single-player with at least one character, probably Gaige. And I will have fun doing it.
This is THE co-op Sci-fi RPG looter shooter. Even after so long, even with an outdated bare-bones fast-travel system, it's still one of the best of it's kind.

Even after what I'm about to say, I still think this game was a 10/10 when I wrote my first review for it (at its peak)

I decided to go back and run a fresh character through for a bit of nostalgia. Most of my experience was positive. BUT I think the difficulty hike immediately after the Bunker and for the remainder of the game started to exhaust me. Could be a skill issue, could be that I didn't itemize well, could be that Gunzerker just isn't a great solo option for NG, but it felt pretty abysmal to hit FFYL a couple dozen times between boss missions and not drop once during the boss itself. That amount of down up down up cycling pushed me to just get to the end asap. I could tell they wanted the player to do side content to over level the quest's recommended level, but that urge to do side content should be organic, not coerced. 

However, that's my only gripe. The comedy still lands, missions are still bonkers, and the loot is still fun to tinker with. I'm gonna take a break and revisit the DLCs at some point, but I decided to jump over to Pre-Sequel to see how my experience compared (and posted an updated review for that too)

"Borderlands 2" is an action-packed first-person shooter that excels in delivering a wild and humorous ride through the unpredictable world of Pandora. With its unique blend of frenetic combat, irreverent humor, and engaging looter-shooter mechanics, it stands as a standout title in the genre.

The game's narrative is driven by witty humor, memorable characters, and a compelling storyline. Players assume the role of Vault Hunters tasked with stopping the tyrannical Handsome Jack from taking over Pandora. The charismatic and eccentric characters, along with the clever writing, create a captivating world filled with quirky personalities and unexpected twists.

Gameplay-wise, "Borderlands 2" shines with its addictive looter-shooter mechanics. The game offers a vast array of weapons with randomly generated stats, encouraging experimentation and creating a sense of excitement in discovering new gear. The skill trees for each character class provide depth and variety, allowing players to tailor their playstyle and abilities.

Visually, the game adopts a cel-shaded art style that adds to its unique and vibrant aesthetic. The colorful and detailed environments, coupled with a diverse range of enemies and bosses, contribute to an immersive experience.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect is a highlight of "Borderlands 2." Playing with friends enhances the chaotic and fun-filled experience, allowing for cooperative gameplay, shared loot, and chaotic battles against enemies.

However, while the game excels in various aspects, some players might find the humor and storytelling style polarizing. Additionally, the repetitive nature of missions and side quests, especially in the late game, might lead to a feeling of monotony for some players.

Overall, "Borderlands 2" is a fantastic game that I highly recommend, especially to fans of action-packed shooters and looter games. Its engaging storyline, humorous dialogue, addictive loot system, and cooperative multiplayer make it a must-play for those seeking a chaotic and entertaining gaming experience. Despite potential repetitive elements, the game's strengths in gameplay variety, character development, and humor overshadow any minor drawbacks, making it an absolute recommendation for FPS enthusiasts.

The game itself is incredibly enjoyable, even when played solo. The storyline stands out as one of the best, featuring a memorable villain in the realm of video games. However, despite these merits, I hesitate to recommend the game. The issue lies in its constant connection requirement to a server, even in offline mode. The server's stability is questionable, with random disconnections that can abruptly kick you out of your current game session, causing you to lose around 20 minutes of progress without warning. If you're willing to accept the risk of encountering this disconnect issue, give the game a try‚Äîperhaps you'll have better luck than I did.

Completely mind blown by how well this game still holds up graphics wise after 10 years. I also had no issues with fps. I'm running on a GTX1650 laptop and I can run max graphics settings with 100+fps. The game play is even better. I initially clicked play just to check out the game for a bit but accidentally lost 6 hours of my life to CL4P TRAP's NONSTOP BULLLS*** and also the uniqueness, beauty of Pandora. 

Everything about this game has so much character and personality. I was literally hooked from the cutscene near the start. They really put so much effort into making the experience immersive. Basically after the intro, you are guided by an NPC throughout the journey, they actually play quite an important despite funny role in the story. The way CL4PTRAP interacts with the player from start to end makes the experience even more so immersive. You can really tell that the devs REALLY love what they're doing. 

I am currently 6.5 hours in but I'm already hooked. Everything feels so lively which is what I believe makes it feel so real. I was also thoroughly immersed in being a Vault Hunter, and didn't even realize it gets better than this until I discovered multiplayer. Joined a session with a rando and had so much fun blasting enemies around and stealing each others loot. 

There is almost nothing to complain about this game, its very forgiving despite its challenging game play, there are a multitude of weapons, and all of em are so unique and intriguing to find and unlock. There's even a very unique element system, where some weapons come with element damage bonuses. And to defeat certain enemies, you'd have to combo different elements, which means you'd have to bring multiple weapons of different elements, but also different weapon types so that you deal enough damage. The enemies, to me, are ACTUALLY TOUGH and you actually have to keep your brain awake unlike many other RPG games where you just shut off your brain and let your character do the work for you. 

Overall this was an easy 69/10 for me. Way better than what I initally expected. It's a shame knowing how much the rest of the world is missing out on. I do personally play Warframe. But they are both relatively really great games with their own personality. Just to point out, as a fellow Tenno, I advise that you REALLY give this game a try. It might just climb up your Looter-Shooter tier list. <3

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
[b] Old children's game that is a waste of time for the average person. [/b] 
‚Äá
‚Äá
‚Äá
This game is a comedy-action first-person looter shooter with sluggish movement, boring action, and bad combat. It features forgettable characters running around killing forgettable enemies with hundreds of forgettable guns. Although the game touts 17 million different guns, these differences hardly have any distinguishing features or characteristics, making them tedious and repetitive to farm. The main story is also lackluster, with a predictable plot and full of cliches.
The surface-level character design makes it difficult to get attached to any of the characters, as they are either gimmicky or simply a woman. No joke the female characters in the game are so uninspired and bland, with no real personality traits whatsoever to the point that them just being women is the only noticeable thing about them (not like the male characters are any better). The game is a number simulator with little to no difficulty in gameplay, making it geared towards children, and it basically is a children's game in every other way too.
It only got to where it is because of its goofy and wacky characters that are so lmao out loud epic funny relatable: "Somebody open me up and put out the fire in my belly... Put it out with knives and bullets and strangling, or I will eat your nephews...". This is awful. 2013 humor and nostalgia I guess is why people still defend it to this day. Despite the numerous quality of life improvements available through mods, the game is ultimately a chore to play.

TL-DR: Fun, unique shooter but far too grindy for a singleplayer experience.

PROS: 

+ Gorgeous vista's with fun graphics.
+ Fun gameplay and a plethora of weapons with different characters to choose from.
+ Kinda funny game too. I used to hate Claptrap at first glance but I grew to like him.
+ Great and smooth port.

CONS:

- Personally, I put the game down about 6 hours in. It was just too grindy. Enemies took way too much damage, the game is foremostly designed for co-op play.

Overall, I recommend only if you have a posse and you all plan to play the same game. I don't really recommend it for single player gameplay though. The game is just not designed with that in mind, but it is still a good game.

Game's good, but here is a recipe for a classic Black Forest Cake:

Ingredients:

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 cup granulated sugar
1/2 cup unsweetened cocoa powder
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp baking soda
1/4 tsp salt
1/2 cup unsalted butter, at room temperature
2 eggs
1 tsp vanilla extract
1/2 cup buttermilk
1 cup brewed cherries
1 cup heavy cream
1/2 cup powdered sugar
1 tsp vanilla extract
Chocolate shavings, for decoration (optional)

Instructions:

Preheat the oven to 350¬∞F (180¬∞C). Grease and flour three 8-inch round cake pans.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
In a separate large bowl, cream the butter until light and fluffy. Add the eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Stir in the vanilla extract.
Gradually add the dry ingredients to the butter mixture, alternating with the buttermilk, and mix until just combined.
Fold in the cherries.
Divide the batter evenly among the prepared pans and smooth the tops.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cakes comes out clean.
Let the cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then remove them from the pans and transfer them to a wire rack to cool completely.
While the cakes are cooling, prepare the whipped cream. In a large bowl, beat the heavy cream, powdered sugar, and vanilla extract until stiff peaks form.
To assemble the cake, place one cake layer on a serving plate. Spread a layer of whipped cream over the top, then top with another cake layer. Repeat with the remaining layers, reserving some whipped cream for the top and sides of the cake.
Decorate the top and sides of the cake with the remaining whipped cream and chocolate shavings (if using).
Chill the cake for at least 1 hour before serving.
Enjoy your delicious homemade Black Forest Cake!

Revisiting Borderlands 2 on a new account was like reconnecting with an old friend. The unique art style, humor, and addictive gameplay are timeless. Despite buying it again, the experience feels as fresh as ever. Here's to the joy of looting and shooting in the chaotic world of Pandora. Borderlands 2, you've still got it.

The first borderlands was a fun and unique game when it came out, but I will never go back to it after I played this game. The game play is pretty much the same, but this time it feels much more fluent

Vault Hunters, rejoice! Borderlands 2 is a Pandora-sized barrel of laughs and loot. It's like someone turned a shooter game into a stand-up comedy night at the local Claptrap club.

The characters are more eccentric than my Aunt Mildred's collection of talking cacti. Handsome Jack is the villain you love to hate, and Claptrap? That little robot has more personality than some of my exes.

Guns, oh the guns! It's like Christmas morning every time you open a chest. Exploding, acid-spewing, and occasionally insulting guns ‚Äì the variety is more extensive than my excuses for being late.

The co-op gameplay is a friendship forge. Nothing says bonding like running over bandits in a hijacked vehicle while debating which gun looks cooler.

Borderlands 2, you had me at "Heyoo!" Thanks for the hilarity, the chaos, and the bazillion guns. Vault hunting has never been this entertaining.

It's hard to explain why but this a must play game. I don't think there is any game that I have played that kept me as engaged no matter how many times I replayed it. In my opinion this is one of the greatest games of all time and definitely my favorite looter-shooter of all time

I never thought this game would be this fun. A friend recommended this to me, and I just purchased it during a sale. At first, it was challenging since levelling up initially seems a bit painful, but that's everywhere in most games (opinion). But once better gear and weapons drop, I am sure you'll have so much fun. 

I would seriously recommend getting the GOTY at first. If you have enjoyed yourself, maxed out, and would continue even more, perhaps it's time to get the Ultimate Vault Hunter Pack#2 and move forward in the most adventurous journey. 

Points I would want to stress on:-

¬∑ The graphics are just to comical and different than what I have seen. I absolutely love it. 

¬∑ The game is hilarious on so many levels

¬∑ The game can be played by yourself and with your mates, but then again it isn't always a good idea to play alone cause... Well, playing with someone would give you the upper advantage, help you beat the enemies faster, and you never know when you need help.

¬∑ Guns? A lot, yes.

¬∑ The achievements are really fun too get. 

¬∑ I love the overall story too.

These are most of the things I'd say, but seriously, get it. Don't have second thoughts. Get some friends, get your communication skills up and shoot every mother****in' people in the game. [spoiler]Except your friends though[/spoiler]

GUNS and GUNS are what you are in for and this game delivers, instant classics.

After 500 plus hours of playing, I realized that no other Borderlands title can beat Borderlands 2 (And yes, I did play Borderlands 3). Story wise, great writing and great characters and character developments. Characters that die in the game doesn't feel forced, and their deaths do make a heavy impact in the plot. Speaking of, the plot is good, and the humor makes it even better. Gameplay wise, straight forward on normal mode, however when you decide to play on higher and more difficult levels, things will get more complicated. Lots of farming for good gear and experimenting with builds for general mobbing, bossing and raid bossing. All in all, this game is amazing. Go pick it up on sale at par with the handsome collection so you'll get all the DLCs for borderlands 2 and you'll also get the pre sequel and all of its DLCs too.

Awful online requirements (even if play alone). It will sometimes randomly set you back to online even after you set yourself to offline. Also you need to reset yourself back to offline everytime you start the game or if you have to reload due to a glitch. That happens often. 

Was much better years ago, they totally ruined this.

It can be fun but it is clearly not designed for solo play, which makes some scenarios and fights almost impossible, despite you being seriously overlevelled and everything else being super easy. Often due to random invisble walls that get you stuck or make it impossible to hit enemies, while you get randomly hit due to animations not being shown properly.

Have tried two of the DLC and must say they both were very meh, kind of having f un collecting stuff but the enemies were more like annoying bugs you swat away. None of the bosses were even remotely difficult (not even when the level was slightly above mine). Except the post story bosses, which are invicible unless you have kept some weapons and prepare your homework by studying online guides. Not enjoyable.

The other DLC, was really crap, especially at the end, some quirky characters but mostly running around swatting flies as the enemies were not scaled and went down so fast it wasn't even funny. But the end, was so lame, your "frenemy" just disappears, you get literelly no treause. Just a completely empty treasure room. Hopped down tried to find if there maybe was an entrance to a secret stash and got stuck. The jumping is sometimes is sometimes insanely far and high but a stone block will trap the character.

Honestly if I didn't like working off lists and if getting headshots wasn't so insanely satisfying, I wouldn't bother at all with this buggy mess.

Now that I think about it, the ending of the main campaign was also pretty meh, just way too easy.

I was looking for a game that was affordable and would work with my integrated graphics card and so I bought this.After completing the game on normal and now in TVHM(which is like a new game+ but your progress such as skills,guns,mods etc are carried over) I can surely say this game is a pretty good bang for your buck.The graphics are kinda dated but still hold up pretty well for a game that is 11 years old.
The gameplay is easy to learn and not to hard to master.
The length is around 60 hrs for a single playthrough if you take your time and try to do the side quests,but that is just my opinion because I do not play a lot of games.
A bit of stuttering is seen but not during the action which is valid considering I do not own a gaming PC

Also,the game is kinda boring for the starting of an hour or two(which is exactly at this point I started to regret buying the game) but after that it catches quite the pace and you would not feel like shutting the game down and just keep on playing.

To sum it all up,if a person is looking to buy something on sale and does not have a powerful PC then this game is worth buying

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!
"POP goes the bandit!"

Borderlands 2, developed by Gearbox Software, is a highly acclaimed shooter-RPG that takes players on a thrilling and irreverent journey through the chaotic world of Pandora. With its unique blend of first-person shooting, RPG elements, and a vast arsenal of crazy weapons, Borderlands 2 offers a captivating gameplay experience that has won the hearts of gamers worldwide. In this review, I'll delve into the key aspects that make this game a true gem in the genre.

Unforgettable Characters and Storyline:
Borderlands 2 boasts a memorable cast of characters, each with their own distinct personality and quirks. From the charismatic yet villainous Handsome Jack to the lovable and hilarious Claptrap, the game's writing and voice acting bring the world of Pandora to life. The storyline is engaging, filled with humor, twists, and moments of genuine emotion, making it a standout feature that keeps players invested in the game's universe.

Vibrant and Immersive World:
Pandora, the game's setting, is a visually stunning and immersive world filled with diverse environments ranging from barren deserts to lush jungles. The cel-shaded art style provides a unique and vibrant aesthetic that perfectly complements the game's offbeat humor and over-the-top action. Exploring Pandora's vast landscapes and stumbling upon hidden areas and loot-filled chests is a joy in itself.

Endless Arsenal of Insane Weapons:
One of the defining features of Borderlands 2 is its mind-boggling array of weapons. From pistols that shoot rockets to shotguns that set enemies on fire, the game's arsenal is a testament to creative design and sheer absurdity. The randomized weapon generation system ensures that every playthrough offers new and exciting guns to discover, encouraging experimentation and customization of playstyles.

Deep RPG Progression System:
Borderlands 2 seamlessly combines first-person shooting with RPG mechanics, allowing players to level up their characters, unlock new skills, and specialize in different playstyles. The three unique skill trees for each character offer a wide range of abilities, giving players the freedom to tailor their character progression to suit their preferred combat style. The feeling of growth and empowerment as you become more powerful is incredibly satisfying.

Cooperative Multiplayer:
Borderlands 2 shines in its cooperative multiplayer mode, allowing up to four players to team up and tackle the game's challenges together. The seamless drop-in, drop-out functionality and the ability to share loot and revive fallen comrades make for a highly enjoyable and chaotic cooperative experience. Playing with friends and combining different character abilities adds another layer of excitement and strategic depth to the gameplay.

Expansive Content and Replayability:
With a main campaign that offers hours of gameplay and a wealth of side quests, challenges, and DLC expansions, Borderlands 2 has an abundance of content to keep players engaged. The game's replayability is further enhanced by the New Game Plus mode, which allows you to start the game again with your upgraded character, facing tougher enemies and finding even more powerful loot.

Conclusion:
Borderlands 2 is an exceptional shooter-RPG that excels in its memorable characters, engaging storyline, and addictive gameplay. The combination of first-person shooting, RPG progression, and a vast arsenal of wacky weapons creates a unique and thrilling experience. Whether you're exploring the visually stunning world of Pandora alone or teaming up with friends in cooperative multiplayer, Borderlands 2 offers an unforgettable adventure that will keep you entertained for hours on end. Prepare to immerse yourself in a wild and wacky universe where chaos and humor reign supreme.

This Borderlands sequel, in truth, appears to hew closely to the formula of its predecessor, with certain notable deviations that may not appeal to everyone. The most striking among these changes is the heightened emphasis on sophomoric humor and an overtly quirky narrative, both of which might be off-putting to players seeking a more mature or nuanced storytelling experience. Furthermore, the limited and uninspired skill tree system, when compared to contemporary game designs, leaves much to be desired and fails to evolve meaningfully from the original title.

In terms of gameplay, Borderlands 2 introduces certain balance issues that undermine the need for player skill. The most glaring example is the disproportionately powerful abilities of specific character classes, allowing them to eliminate foes with a single shot and frequently transition into area-of-effect attacks that obliterate all opposition. This imbalance not only diminishes the need for accuracy but also makes encounters feel overly predictable and lacking in challenge. In the short term, the primary challenge lies in managing ammunition supplies when faced with hordes of regular enemies and occasional tank-like adversaries. This, unfortunately, leads to a sense of repetitiveness, making Borderlands 2 feel like a mindless loot-fueled escapade rather than an engaging gaming experience.

One of the more disappointing aspects of the game is the relentless barrage of fetch quests. Players are persistently tasked with running and gunning through various areas to complete such quests. The narrative and dialogue accompanying these tasks are characterized by a highly idiosyncratic style that might be divisive, with some players finding it quirky and entertaining, while others may perceive it as grating and over-the-top.

Moreover, Borderlands 2 incorporates in-game advertisements for downloadable content and other game extras, forcing players to encounter these ads on the title screen and at certain points when fast-traveling. This commercial intrusion disrupts the immersion in the game and feels like an unnecessary intrusion into the gaming experience.
