[h1] [i] Not for everybody [/i] [/h1]
Let me preface this by saying; BL2 is an acquired taste and it is NOT for everybody.
When I originally started playing Borderlands a couple of years ago (started wit BL1) I honestly wasn't much of a fan. I had seen some gameplay previously (notably of 2 & 3) and thought that the games [i] looked [/i] interesting and fun but quickly realized that they really weren't for me... the problem is that while the Borderlands community will tell you that especially 2 has a great story and villain, even though the story is like a 4.5/10 and Handsome Jack like an 8.5/10. You have to realize that Borderlands isn't about the story and it never has been either. Borderlands really is about the mindless activity of killing a guy and reloading a map over and over again untill you're happy with what he dropped. I say "mindless" because thats what it is. You're not really thinking about what you're doing, you're just doing it untill youre finished. But I still rate this game positively; why is that? As I said, Borderlands is an acquired taste. As long as you recognize that it's just there to kill some [strike] enemies [/strike]  time and get a higher number on a weapon you want you will have a good time. It might take some getting used to and it might seem dull at first but trust me when, when you really haven't got anything better to do and you don't feel like playing another game you will probably have some fun. 8/10

Borderlands 2 is very nice game. Story is nice,doenst take itself seriously, but has some nice drama to it, characters are well written, many side missions and a TON OF LOOT, also you can play in coop. In this game you are playing as 4 new heroes that being - Axton (he has a turret and is more of a army guy), Salvador (Maniac and can dualwield weapons), Maya (Is a siren so she uses magic) and Zer0 (ninja with a cool sword) and two DLC characters (Gaige and Krieg). Villain in this story is name Handsome Jack.  AND DAYUM he is well written. Evil as all hell in his quest to open a vault on Pandora and take control of the guardian of the vault. Our heroes must stop him before he opens the vault. Gameplay is practicly normal - not fast but sometimes slugish. Easter eggs are in this game too and there is many of them. Now side characters - Markus (sell weapons on Pandora and NO REFUNDS! Remember that or he will blow your head off. My second favourite ). Next is Moxxi - in short - sexy b*tch, but she is well written. Next is Hammerlock - a gentleman and second character that appears. Next is Doctor Zed - he is not rly a doctor, but he is the one who heals you and sell you shields that you WILL NEED! Next is my and Mikes favourite character and that is Tiny Tina - she is cute, sounds nice and ofcourse funny as all hell. Mikes favourire, because he screamed when he heard her. And ofcourse there are heroes from the first borderlands - that being Lilith, Brick, Roland and Mordecai with his bird. And ofcourse Claptrap - goofy and annoying but in the end well written. Leveling system is normal - kill = experience. Many enemies from bandits to some army guys that serve Jack. Many bossfights. They say the last boss is dissapointing, but me and my friend say different, we enjoyed the humor and the story so it is well deserved 8/10.

[h1]Verdict:
B Tier,
7/10,
3.5 stars,
[/h1]

[b]Worth a Buy?[/b]
- Most definitely, especially if you want to play Co-Op with your friends. Though it would be wise to purchase this during a sale. You can skip the GOTY edition if you'd like because most of the DLC is post-game content and cosmetics. 

[b]Disclaimer[/b]
- This review is based on a single-player experience, not the multiplayer co-op experience, so it does not accurately represent that.

[b]The Good:[/b]
- Blood and gore.
- 12GB install size.
- The art is incredibly distinctive and iconic. It has the feeling of an interactive comic book.
- The game's visuals and aesthetic make it ageless.
- The UI design blends in effectively with the art style.
- When a character makes their initial appearance, a cool intro is played.
- Characters are enjoyable and memorable in a positive way.
- Handsome Jack makes for an excellent antagonist.
- Great voice acting.
- Co-Op for 4 players.
- Solo gaming is still a viable alternative.
- Extremely replayable.
- The skill tree that can be respecced for a fee.
- Contains numerous secrets and easter eggs.
- There are two new game plus+ modes: "True Vault Hunter Mode" and "Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode."


[b]The Bad:[/b]
- Awful DLC policy.
- Unskippable cutscenes makes replaying very tedious.
- On current PCs, performance can be inconsistent necessitating the use of DXVK.
- The abundance of weapons and equipment in the game can feel overwhelming. As you advance, your equipment will also gradually become obsolete.  
- The limited number of slots and bank space you'll have, as mentioned above, makes this situation worse. Upgrades are a way to increase the amount. It remains too low, however, despite that. If you are a gaming hoarder, you will detest this. 
- The game restricts exploration by putting up invisible boundaries and kill zones.
- Has a terrible, contrived story twist occur during the mission "Where Angels Fear to Tread (Part 2)".
- Echo devices, which are voice recordings, are not preserved in the game; instead, they respawn for some reason. 
- Other voicelines can cancel voicelines, which can be annoying. 
- You can't track multiple quests at a time.
- The game occasionally feels repetitive.

[b]The Neutral & Informational:[/b]
- You can bypass the initial start-up videos by typing "NoStartupMovies" in the Steam startup settings.
- A lot of extra optional side quests.
- Mostly silent protagonist.
- It might be hit or miss when it comes to quirky dialogue. Though the quirky dialogue isn't as awful as in other games, if you dislike this type of dialogue, you may dislike this game.
- Story writing does not take itself seriously, though it does at times, which can feel inconsistent.
- Is divided into segments in a semi-open world design.
- Has no fall damage, which is great but unrealistic.
- Cutscenes/Cinemamatics are capped at 30fps.
- Because levelling can feel a little slow, character creation is mostly an end-game activity.
- Completing the main story and various side quests took me 32 hours. With the inclusion of new game plus and DLCs, your play time might easily reach the hundreds of hours.

[b]Performance:
Windows 11, 165hz 1080p Monitor, GPU: 8GB RTX 3060Ti, CPU: Intel Core i7-12700F, 16GB DDR4 3200MHz RAM, SSD [/b]
- While easily obtaining 60 frames per second or more, the frame rate and frame time can feel inconsistent. If you want a few more frames, I strongly advise you to set the PhysX setting to low and reduce the view distance. Installing DXVK, which can significantly improve your performance, is also the most important improvement. Here is a guide if you need one. https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Borderlands_2#DXVK


[b]Bugs & Glitches:[/b]
- When you initially start the game or alt-tab, it changes your default desktop resolution and refresh rate to match the game's. 
- The game launcher crashes every time whenever you hover over the news section.
- A crash occurred during the Tiny Tina birthday party mission.
- There was also an infinite loop where the game kept "creating an online session".

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
- Since each player won't have the same equipment, the difficulty can vary depending on their gaming experience. As a result, the difficulty can fluctuate depending on the quality of your items. The degree of difficulty was reasonable during my time, and if a mission was too challenging, I would just do several side missions to level up and acquire stronger gear.

[b]Additional Information:[/b]
[b]- That plot moment:[/b] [spoiler]During the mission "Where Angels Fear to Tread (Part 2)". A very awful moment occurs in the story writing, which I will now explain. During the final cutscene, Roland is shot through the chest by Handsome Jack, who literally teleports behind him. Roland is then killed by a single bullet. Roland was taken out by a single bullet, despite the fact that everyone was protected by shields and are bullet sponges. Lilith then starts to attack when Jack abruptly strikes her in the neck, implanting a collar that now has control over her. Jack then monologues while your character does absolutely nothing during all of this. Lilith then teleports you away rather than killing you as Jack had commanded. [/spoiler]To develop the plot, this entire sequence felt stupid and forced. 

[b]- Conclusion:[/b] Particularly in terms of the graphics and artistic style, Borderlands 2 has aged incredibly well. Since anything is more enjoyable with friends, the game's inclusion of Co-Op is a great feature. If you truly enjoy looter shooters, this game is for you; however, if you're looking for a serious, story-driven experience, look elsewhere.

Borderlands 2, receiving a lukewarm 3/10 from my perspective, sits in the realm of mediocrity for me. While I recognize its appeal, it's just not my cup of tea. The gameplay feels repetitive, boiling down to a monotonous cycle of shoot, loot, repeat. However, I could force myself to trudge through an hour, appreciating the game's appeal to those who relish the mindless thrill of gunning down enemies. Its unique art style and quirky humor might resonate with some, but the lack of depth and variety left me unimpressed. It's a title perfectly suited for those who thrive on relentless, straightforward shoot-'em-up experiences.

As a Destiny 2 veteran, I appreciate Borderlands 2 for its strengths. 

The game boasts fantastic guns and gameplay, with an incredible perk system, though it's not flawless. 
The writing is inconsistent, with great moments but lots of jokes that feel as though they were written by a "dank" Redditor. While the guns are fun, the lack of an upgrade system is disappointing, and gameplay tends suffer from hit detection issues. Despite the graphics not being groundbreaking, the diverse enemies and vast environments are a plus. 

Is it the greatest game of all time? No. But it is a fun looter-shooter experience that doesn't waste your time.

Borderlands 2 is like a cup of hot chocolate on a cold winter's night, a subtle breeze on a warm summer's day, the smell of the forest in the crisp spring air. I can't think of a game I've played more consistently across all generations of consoles I've owned since it released. I know every story beat, strat, joke, meta, waypoint, and cheese. I should've been done with this game long ago. There is no reason I have left to play it. For me, there is nothing new to discover. Yet, every now and again, there is the distant beckoning call. The call to listen to more 2012-era internet humor and f*ck up Terramorphous with the Bee Shield + Conference Call. The call to soak in the atmosphere of The Highlands while imagining life as a Zaford bartender. The call to crit-stack with snipers and become a one hit kill machine on UVHM. Gearbox will never again capture lightning in a bottle like this. 10+ years on and it is still one of, if not my favorite game of all time. It is absolute peak.

Hold onto your loot, Vault Hunters, because we're diving into the world of Borderlands 2, a game that's so absurdly hilarious it makes even the most hardcore psycho bandit crack a smile!

First, let's talk about the characters. You've got Handsome Jack, a villain so charming you'll almost forget he's trying to kill you. He's like the guy at the office who steals your lunch but does it with such panache that you can't even be mad. Then there's Claptrap, the robot with delusions of grandeur. He's like that one friend who's always volunteering to DJ at parties, despite having the musical taste of a kazoo stuck in a blender.

The game's setting, Pandora, is a delightful wasteland where everything is trying to kill you. Seriously, the local wildlife must've watched a few too many action movies because they come at you like they're auditioning for a role in the next Mad Max film. And don't even get me started on the psychos - they're the kind of folks who probably end their love letters with "Yours psychotically."

But the real stars of the show are the guns. Borderlands 2 has more guns than you have relatives on Facebook. They come in all shapes, sizes, and flavors - from shotguns that shoot fire to sniper rifles that talk back to you. It's like Santa's workshop, but instead of toys, they make instruments of destruction.

And speaking of destruction, the game's humor is more explosive than a barrel of TNT. The writing is sharp, witty, and as absurd as a clown riding a unicycle through a burning circus. You'll find yourself laughing at the darkest, most inappropriate jokes while casually blowing up bandits and robots. It's a bizarre mix of comedy and carnage that somehow works like a charm.

The quests in Borderlands 2 are like a never-ending parade of absurdity. From collecting pizza ingredients for a psychotic robot to hunting down mutant midgets, you'll wonder if the writers were locked in a room with nothing but caffeine and comic books for inspiration.

If you play co-op with friends, it's even better. The game's chaos level is cranked up to 11, and you'll be fighting over loot like kids in a candy store during a Black Friday sale. Plus, who can resist a friendly duel where you can shoot your buddies in the face while yelling, "This is what friendship looks like in Pandora!"

In the end, Borderlands 2 is a glorious, chaotic, and hilarious mess of a game. It's like a party where the pinata is filled with grenades, and the cake is a giant explosion. So grab your friends, load up on guns, and get ready for a rollercoaster ride through a world that's as insane as it is side-splittingly funny. Welcome to Pandora, Vault Hunters ‚Äì you're in for a wild, wacky ride!

Laughably gimmicky and incredibly boring game. Not even worth the few bucks paid for it or the drive space.

Game is hugely unbalanced, constantly swarms players almost "Serious Sam" style but gives you severe mag/ammo cap, inventory cap, you're always emptying whole clips, wasting multiple mags, to down 1 or 2 enemies, while more spawn. "Out of AmmoLands Poo" or "Reloaderland Poo" is what this poo of game should be called. The reload animations are excruciatingly slow as well. These issues were also found in Duke Nukem Forever. The unfunny, crude, tasteless humor and whole "always out of ammo, switching weapons, vastly-under-powered weapons" thing seems inspired by DNF. That game sucked, btw.

Despite obtaining this on a huge sale, it was way overpriced in my opinion.
Games are intended to be fun and rewarding, but none of that is found here. For example, weapons will drop that are above your level, you can't use them as a result of that, but have weaker stats than what you already have. No matter how powerful a weapon is that you obtain, the world "levels up with you" but the enemies are always really about 5 levels stronger than the player. The game constantly ambushes the player forcing to fight zerging enemies, bat swarms, monster swarms, ranged enemies, pyro-flamethrower dudes, all at the same time. You'll run out of ammo in no time and barely dent any of them.

That's not fun. That's POS gameplay and design. I also doubt many of the positive reviews, they offer no substance about the actual game "iT's gReAt! cOoL! So aWeSoME!", yeah right, I call BS.

The vehicles in the game have crap controls, you have to drive around world with gimmick design not intended for vehicles so have fun smashing into everything like a playing rusty bumper-cars klanging about.

Easy -1/10. I actually found it so unfun, that it was rather insulting.
If the loot is trash then it's not a looter-shooter game but trash-shooter.
If you run out of ammo all the time and have to stand there constantly waiting to reload or changing weapons, then it's a trash-reloader.

Henceforth, this game shall be known as:

Trash-Reloaderland 2: Electric Out-of-Ammo Poo

Crazy how I hadn't made a review for this game yet. This is one of few games I've falled in love with from the first few minutes played. I'm having an absolute blast (literally) playing the Borderlands games.

Borderlands 2 can be found on most Best Games of All Time Lists, and it absolutely deserves the spot. The real birth of the looter shooter genre was here, in addition to a visual style that remains beautiful and stylish all these years later. Not only does it have multiple distinct classes with unique gameplay and personalities, not only does it have like a bazillion guns to hunt and farm for, but it also one of the greatest, or even the greatest villains in video game history, Handsome Jack. Yes, this game has aged, obviously, but it has lost none of its fun and edge and charm, and it is, in my opinion, a true masterpiece. 

Borderlands 2 is the best of all the Borderlands games, and while 3 had the smoothest gameplay and updated visuals, the writing and characters were some of the worst I've ever seen anywhere ever, and then they doubled down on already terrible writing by making every character gay or some bullsh*t, with some of the cringiest "villains" I've ever had the displeasure to see. Borderlands 2 though, is as clever and meta and darkly funny as ever, with the basis of the humor being everyone on Pandora is a varying degree of bast*rd. I genuinely laughed out loud on numerous occasions, mostly because of Handsome Jack, but there were a lot of other hilarious lines and missions from other characters too. Speaking of which, the missions were surprisingly interesting and funny, as much as the main story, which is surprising as this is a looter shooter, and missions usually only exist to propel you forward into combat. Not so here, each mission felt like there was purpose in it, and I really did have fun doing them. Except for this game's biggest issue. The Goddam map and UI.

The map and quest markers are my biggest gripe with this otherwise wonderful experience, most of the time I had no idea where to go, whether something was up or down, how far away, and I often ended up on Google looking for the right way. Pretty much all my frustrations in the game stem from this issue, so I just wanted to point that out. 

Other than that though, I had a phenomenal time, with my two favourite classes being Gaige and Krieg, because of both gameplay and personalities. Sadly the characters you play don't really have voiced dialogue, but they do have plenty of voice lines, really letting their personalities shine in the best way. I can't help but grin every time Gaige yells "Domo Arigato suckaaas", or makes a comment about which gun to pick up or whatever, and the same goes for Krieg, on top of the incredibly satisfying class mechanics and absolutely crazy builds you can get going. 

The combination of the beautiful world and visual style, varied and layered classes with fantastic gunplay, hilarious characters and writing and perhaps the best villain in a game makes Borderlands 2 a must-recommend for anyone who likes guns, westerns, dark and zany humor, or just good games in general. One of the greatest games ever made.

PS: Get all the DLCs too, they're absolutely phenomenal, and arguably the best content in the game.

Borderlands 2 is an incredibly fun and addictive game that offers unique gameplay and a ton of different features.

Firstly, it is worth noting the bright and stylish graphics of the game. The fascinating post-apocalyptic world is simply breathtaking, and the detail of the characters and environment creates the feeling of being inside the game universe.

One of the main advantages of Borderlands 2 is its unique weapon system. Tens of thousands of weapon combinations provide virtually endless weapon selection options. Each weapon feels unique, and the arsenal that can be collected is simply breathtaking. You can use either regular firearms or exotic ones from fairy tales. Each weapon has its own characteristics, so you will never get bored throughout the game.

Moreover, Borderlands 2 offers an exciting story and many interesting quests. You have to go on dangerous adventures and fight many enemies. All this is made even more interesting thanks to the wonderful humor and funny dialogues of the characters, who always try to please the player with their jokes.

The game also offers the opportunity to collaborate with friends in multiplayer mode. This makes the gameplay even more fun and interesting, since you can fight together and support each other in battles.

Borderlands 2 is a game that will definitely not leave you indifferent. It skillfully combines different genres and experiences, making you come back to it again and again. If you love action and adventure, I highly recommend you give Borderlands 2 a try.

I just finished BL2 - over 10 years after its release.  For its time it was probably amazing.  By today's standards...eh.  The core gameplay (shooting) feels old: jumpy, imprecise -- not nearly as fluid as modern shooters.  Melee is an afterthought.   Level design is good.  Handsome Jack is a great villain.  Overall I enjoyed it, but not as much as Tiny Tina's Wonderlands, or Vermintide.

Unpopular opinion, but I am entitled to it. 

I played the first Borderlands, couch co-op with my uncle and it was a very rewarding experience. It was the first looter-shooter at least that I had heard of at the time. I lean towards RPGs, but I had played quite a bit of Halo, again couch co-op with my uncle. This will make more sense later, but Halo's campaign is still massively enjoyable in single-player.

I enjoyed Borderlands so much that I pre-ordered Borderlands 2 - with a gifted add-on it was $80. I played it maybe 90 minutes the first day and hated it. Never touched it again until recently. I heard time and time again that it was the best of the series so I wondered if I was being unreasonable, or at least why I wasn't able to enjoy it. So I gave it another chance. I played the campaign and got at least to level 50, before dabbling in DLC that frankly could not hold my attention.

Here's what I don't like:

First and foremost they created something called badass rank, which replaced the previous system of gaining small bonuses for a certain gun type, by using that gun type. It no longer matters what gun you use. While I can see why many people would consider this a positive change, I (being of the RPG mindset) did not. I prefer class depth and specialization. 

Secondly, they turned that annoying clap trap up to 11. He was cute in the first game, and this time around I just wanted to blow his head off. 

So that covers what initially turned me off. Then we get to the gameplay, and the mobs are interesting enough. I'd have to assume playing co-op would have helped my experience, but without that, it felt like an almost joyless grind. Every time I got a weapon that dealt decent enough damage, I was met with a difficulty spike within 2 levels that made the gun obsolete. Side quests were just a means to an end. I skipped through most of the zones, just doing quests, the content wasn't very engaging otherwise. 

The story was decent. Handsome Jack is a great villain - that we can agree on. Even the final boss was fun. Though, I didn't really care what happened to anyone outside of the previous vault hunters. 

Final Score: 4/10

"Borderlands 2" is a vibrant and thrilling computer game that elevates the first-person shooter genre to new heights. Set in the post-apocalyptic world of Pandora, this action-packed game boasts a unique blend of frenetic gunplay, a richly crafted open world, and a healthy dose of irreverent humor.

The graphics in "Borderlands 2" are distinctive and visually arresting, embracing a cel-shaded art style that sets it apart from other games in the genre. The exaggerated character designs and colorful landscapes contribute to the game's lively and energetic atmosphere.

The gameplay is the heart and soul of "Borderlands 2," offering an immense arsenal of guns, each with its own quirks and abilities. The cooperative element enhances the experience, allowing players to team up with friends and tackle the game's challenges together, making the combat and exploration all the more engaging.

One of the game's standout features is its witty and humorous narrative. The dialogues and characters are both memorable and entertaining, injecting a lighthearted tone into the otherwise intense and action-packed gameplay.

A minor drawback could be the occasional repetitiveness in missions and side quests, but the sheer fun of the gameplay and the allure of discovering new weapons typically outweigh this concern.

In summary, "Borderlands 2" is a must-play for fans of first-person shooters. Its dynamic gameplay, richly imaginative world, and comedic storytelling make it a standout title that offers hours of chaotic, adrenaline-fueled excitement for both solo and cooperative players.

"Borderlands 2" is a remarkable sequel that impressively addresses nearly all the aspects I found lacking in the first game. One of the notable improvements is the enhanced A.I., making the gameplay experience feel more dynamic and engaging. The addition of a much-needed minimap and the distinctiveness of various zones further enrich the overall gameplay, setting it apart from its predecessor.

The standout feature of "Borderlands 2" is its captivating story. Unlike the first game, which felt a bit lackluster and slow-paced, this sequel delivers a compelling narrative that kept me enthralled from start to finish. The humor and the development of the characters added depth and charm to the entire experience, ensuring there was never a dull moment.

It's quite rare for a sequel to surpass the original, but "Borderlands 2" achieves just that. The gameplay is an absolute thrill, offering a perfect blend of madness, addictiveness, and rewarding progression. The story, filled with moments that evoke various emotions, mainly laughter, is truly an impressive feat.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, and "Borderlands 2" is no exception. There was a notable performance issue that I encountered initially, despite having a high-end PC. However, the new textures DLC came to the rescue and fixed the problem for me. Despite this, I still had to adjust the settings, such as running the game with PhysX on low and view distance on medium, to optimize performance. Nevertheless, these minor setbacks didn't significantly dampen the overall enjoyment of the game.

For achievement hunters: the game has 75 achievements, with some more challenging than others. It was not an easy task to complete the game. But it is doable and for sure not the hardest out there.

In conclusion, "Borderlands 2" is a shining example of a sequel that excels in every way, surpassing its predecessor in both gameplay and storytelling. The game's addictive and rewarding gameplay, combined with its compelling narrative and humorous moments, create an unforgettable experience. While some performance issues may have lingered, the overall package more than makes up for it. If you're a fan of the series or looking for an action-packed, humorous, and thoroughly enjoyable gaming adventure, "Borderlands 2" is an absolute must-play.

There are a myriad of things I dislike about this game, however why it is I don't recommend it basically boils down to three main reasons:

1. The overall tone.

If you eat fried chicken all the time, you will be physically unhealthy. Similarly, if you constantly consume depraved media you will be mentally/spiritually unhealthy. I am far from being what you would call a puritan, in fact I do enjoy the first tittle in the series. But whereas the first game depicts decent (on some level) people struggling in a lawless and corrupt universe, the other titles instead seem to revel in, and even celebrate that lawlessness. I understand this is largely a matter of perception, but it sets the game up as needing to redeem itself to me straight off the bat.

2. The difficulty, or lack thereof.

It is unchallenging to the point of monotony. I don't consider myself a great FPS player, but I am well seasoned. It is probably intentionally geared towards, younger, or otherwise less skilled players (there's nothing wrong with that), however the complete lack of any difficulty adjustment, seems like a gross oversight. There are challenges but they are too sparse. 

2.a General combat.
It is often possible to stand in the open before a group enemies and simply take one's time to aim for their heads with a sniper rifle. Their weapons are inaccurate and they do not advance towards the player (I am also left feeling like there is a hidden fudge-factor; it just feels too easy to get headshots). How a combat game with such flawed gameplay is so highly rated, I wonder.

2.b There are no stakes anyway.
You basically don't need to buy anything, as enemies, containers and quest rewards give practically anything you could want, so when the only penalty for dying is a small fee, who cares.

3. Game mechanics that incentivise unnatural play-styles.

A skill that causes the first round in a mag to have bonus damage, another one that gives bonus damage for changing weapons; there are numerous features like this that leave player feeling like they are being sub-optimal unless they do silly things. For me this is the clincher and makes me think the developers didn't take their jobs (or the player) seriously.

Conclusion

If you think pointless sexual references are funny, hate being challenged and love being silly, have I got a game for you. 



At the time of this edit (2/10/23), one person found my review funny, therefore the initial review is here below for posterity.

I say this as a fan of the first game: this is overrated and dumb. It has some of the most retarded mechanics I've ever even heard of, such as, swapping weapons giving bonus damage (WTF). The story is uncompelling as a bowl of dog balls. The president of the planet wants you dead for no convincing reason. The Englishman is stock, one dimensional and can't say lieutenant properly. You have to follow the robot for ages, which the developers even lampshade as annoying, but still make you do anyway. Missions are on rails. Skins that do little more than change the tint still cost money. The vast majority of the combat is a cakewalk for an experienced FPS player but there's no difficulty slider. Guns do silly things that abuse the suspension of disbelief. Enemies are so prolific they don't feel like people. The inventory screen is split up pointlessly into floating panels that you have to change the focus from one to the other for NO REASON AT ALL, and it's something you use a lot. There are a fair amount of sexual references that aren't funny and serve no purpose at all.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Borderlands 2 is an amazing game from a great era in gaming. The game still holds up extremely well, given the fact that it released in 2012. You can truly tell lots of love was put into the creation of this game. I originally played this on the Playstation 3 and luckily this is one of those very few games that works just as well on PC. 

This game's biggest problem is how it handles the level system. Enemies and weapons do not properly scale without mods or DLC, even then enemies still just cap at level 72. As a result, the gameplay can almost feel like that of an MMO, due to the amount of damage certain enemies can tank. You will either be doing too much damage, or not enough damage which can make the late game pretty gruelling and boring ESPECIALLY if you wish to get all of the challenges.

With that being said, there's a reason Borderlands 2 was awarded Game of the Year. It truly is one of the most unique games I have ever played and still rivals current games to this day.

This is just a fun game. The story isn't to be taken seriously. There's some great laughs at the characters written here.

I only played one run, as Zero. I did over half of the missions, but I'm not sure how much. I had a blast with all the weapons I found. I experimented a lot with the different sniper rifles, and pistols. It seemed the machine guns had little value to me. Other weapons just did a better job. It would've been nice to be able to mod the weapons, but there was always new gear coming at you. The vehicles were fun and easy to use. I actually didn't mind driving with the keyboard. I usually hate it. 

This game runs extremely well. I don't recall having any bugs that were common, if any at all. I had no frame drops. Solid work here.

The story is what it is. If you do any research, you know what you're getting. It's just good fun. Handsome Jack is great in the role. The side characters are funny, and well done. 

The art style is very cool. It's cartoonish in it's use of the heavy lines. It reminds me of 80's Transformers, and the style used in the Devastation game. It's unique, and I appreciated it.

It's not a great game, but it's a lot of fun.

[h1]TL:DR/ Final Rating - 92/100[/h1]

[b]Add to Cart Now[/b] - Wait for Patches/Light Sale - Wait for Fixes/[b]Deep Sale[/b] - Not worth install

Borderlands 2 is a genre defining title. While the original title laid the foundations of the looter shooter genre, Borderlands 2 surpassed it in just about every way. An absolute classic of the Xbox 360/Playstation 3 era that holds its own better than most even after a decade since release. It goes on sale often so keep an eye out, but it and its dlc are more than worth every penny. I have been playing this game for thousands of hours across generations of platforms since the year it came out and I promise that this is a game that you won‚Äôt want to skip.

[h1]Performance/Options - 96/100[/h1]

Borderlands 2 was originally released for Xbox 360, Playstation 3 and PC on September 18, 2012. That is to say as long as your hardware isn‚Äôt completely potato, you can run it and you can probably run it well. The game is incredibly stable and very rarely has any issues related to framerate or any other metric. The only real issue tends to stem from Phys-X, which can cause major frame drops depending on the guns used and the areas that you find yourself in. I however find it to be more of a gimmick than anything that gets rid of some features  (can't stand or jump on cloth material) and makes it not worth using anyways. Considering the era of games we are in now where performance is often sacrificed, hopping into BL2 feels like a breath of fresh air that just works on almost any system. Settings are easy to adjust in and out of game and have most of the highly needed options for optimal gaming in 2023.

[h1]Visuals/Audio - 90/100[/h1]

Borderlands 2 employs the cell-shaded comic style. It's become so iconic to the franchise that many compare new games that are also cell shaded to ‚Äúlooking like borderlands''. Overall it's pretty well done, The guns look awesome, the character designs work really well and the world really pops out at you when running through it. However, it should be mentioned that some textures have not aged quite as well and will look fuzzy or out of focus, especially in cutscenes. Audio wise the game does a great job. Music is done by Jesper Kidd, who honestly deserves much more credit for the quality of music he puts out for these games. All the regions have really nice ambience and combat music, and boss fights have a level of epicness/tempo that really makes you smile when duking it out. On the other hand, there are some audio bugs/issues that you will run into on a semi-frequent basis. Thankfully nothing game breaking but it something that will probably pop up once or twice in your first playthrough

[h1]Gameplay - 93/100[/h1]

First off, the basics for Gameplay. Borderlands 2 is a first person, looter shooter with characters who have skill trees and unique actions. 4 characters are available in the base game, with 2 others found in dlc. They are all incredibly unique and offer some really fun play styles that make multiple playthrough necessary to get the full experience of the game. Moment to moment gameplay is spent picking up missions or side missions, running through tons of mobbing enemies and facing off against bosses and minibosses in arenas. Endgame consists of grinding for perfect gear from different bosses/missions/raid bosses (bosses that drop the best loot for a challenging fight). The gear in question is guns that have randomized parts and effects that get crazier and crazier as they increase in rarity. The guns are where each borderlands game shines the most, and 2 is no exception to this. You can find uniques and legendaries that put other looter shooter unique effects to shame. Such as a pistol that shoots a line of 8 micro rockets, an smg that can be thrown as a bouncing betty, and even a shotgun that shoots swords that explode. Seriously, these games go crazy with their loot game. Each character can do 3 playthroughs that scale in level and difficulty, with the final playthrough being repeatable if you want to take a max level character through the story again. 
The Playthroughs are done mostly well. Playthrough 1 (Normal Mode) is an easy story drive experience that teaches you the basics of the game, while you learn to balance leveling and farming for gear with the leveling pace of the game. Playthrough 2 (True Vault Hunter Mode) is where the game really shines and has a lot of special moments as the game was designed for this range of gameplay. More builds, more loot and more options on how to play. Playthrough 3 (Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode) has some scaling issues at the absolute top end, but the grind to get there (and if you even just stay away from op5+) is so incredibly recording with some really powerful builds and more loot that you wouldn't have had access to in previous playthroughs. Reaching all the way on each character can be a real challenge but it is absolutely rewarding and provides an experience like no other.
Overall the game and its multiple-playthrough offering of content work really really well to keep you engaged. There's a lot of fun to be had by creating a new character and adding self imposed challenges such as melee only runs or allegiance runs, but even by just playing to make the best character, you will find that the gameplay has a lot to offer. So much so that many of us are starting characters over again just to experience the game over 10 years after it was released. 

[h1]Story - 93/100[/h1]

The Story for Borderlands 2 is fairly simple. The bad guy, Handsome Jack, is trying to take over the planet and wipe you and your friends off the map. He is doing this because he is convinced that he is the hero of everyone's story and that the Borderlands need to be wiped out for him to be able to build his paradise. Oh and he has an army of robots that can be launched from his space station to just about anywhere to fight you. The twists and turns of this game's story are good and everyone plays an interesting role, but there's a reason that Handsome Jack is remembered as one of the best villains in all of gaming. He really steals the show with his twisted, messed up humor that leaves you laughing while also really gunning to take him down. 

[h1]Multiplayer - 95/100[/h1]

Borderlands really embodies the phrase, ‚ÄúGreat alone, but even better with friends‚Äù. Playing solo has some great perks and makes sprinting through the game a breeze. When you add 1-3 friends to your playthrough however, that is when you get the real chaotic mayhem that this game was always meant to have. Characters have different skills to buff one another, the game scales to have more enemies that are harder to kill to shoot at, and the absolutely hilarious scenarios that you all will find yourselves in increase tenfold. Seriously, if you can get a couple of buddies to go a full playthrough with you, it's one of the best experiences in the game.

[h1]DLC/Pricing - 87/100[/h1]

The DLCs for this game can really vary in quality, but because of the way they are all bundled now, it's absolutely worth it. You have 5 headhunters (short mini DLCs that added a questline a boss that were themed around holidays/seasons), the 2 character packs for characters 5 and 6, the 2 ultimate level packs which added 22 additional levels + 8 op levels, And the real meat and potatoes: the 5 main dlc stories that add new areas, new bosses, new loot and much more gameplay (as well as 8 more levels and 2 more op levels from dlc 5). 
As far as pricing nowadays, there's different bundles that include different options and number of DLCs all from $20-120 To me, Borderlands 2 is worth the full price, but it is one of those games that goes on major sales often, so if you're a little tight on budget or wanna wait for a juicy steam sale, the Handsome collection often drops down to as low as $15. Getting that and DLC 5 on sale will get you all of BL2‚Äôs content and Borderlands the Pre Sequel‚Äôs Content for under $20

Fun overall with the biggest weakness being that the game is consistently inconsistent, particularly in combat.

Things I like:
-the visuals
-combat is mostly solid
-the characters and story
-variety in play styles

What I didn't like:

-resilience feels the same regardless of level/build/huge stat numbers. What's the point of more shields and health when you can lose them almost instantly?

-deaths can feel cheap; without rhyme or reason. I get the world of Borderlands is psychotic, but it can be very annoying getting torn a new one and not knowing what did what to you.

-None of the wildlife is fun to fight in Borderlands. You may find them to be a general nuisance.

-Some of the weapons can be overly dangerous to the player, particularly the rocket assault rifles from behind cover. You can hit an object's hitbox even if you appear to have the clear shot. 

I've played this game for many hours on at least five different platforms, and I will recommend it still.

I originally gave up on this series way too quickly. I don't know why, I must not have been in the right mood. I went back and gave it a second chance and loved the first game in the series. This one is a huge improvement across the board in my opinion. Basically, it is a fun arcade shooter with lots going on. It is a looter shooter so you'll constantly seek out different weapons that randomly generate stats until you get into the late game and can find really great unique weapons that are worth keeping for a long time. There are enough differences between the various weapons and the various character classes that you will always be able to tailor the combat to your preferred style. All in all, it makes for a fun experience if you like this sort of thing.

EDIT: I finally finished it and boy was it good. The story actually surprised me at how good it was. I thought it was a generic story at first but it got a lot deeper when you start to learn more about the villain and why he was doing what he was doing.
The game can be really hard at times especially since I play solo. For the most part, just take your time and learn to use the right gear on the right enemy types but even still, there are times it feels like it wasn't properly balanced or something. In the end, the good more than outweighs the bad so I have to say this is one great game. A huge improvement over the first one in my opinion.

Also, side note, install the high res texture pack from the devs. It is free and looks great. The reviews are super mixed though I think most of them are out of date because I didn't have any issues at all due to the texture pack and I just beat the main story just now with the pack enabled the whole game.

EDIT 2: I would like to mention that it took me 97.5 hours to fully complete the main campaign, all 5 DLC campaigns, all 5 headhunter mini-campaigns and every small side quest possible. I didn't complete the big level 50 quests or the raid bosses (though god knows I tried the latter and failed numerous times) but I absolutely got my money's worth.

Also, of note - I had the HD texture pack installed the entire time. I had 1 single crash during the main campaign and 1 single crash during one of the DLC campaigns. That's 2 crashes total across nearly 100 hours of play and neither were reproducible in the same areas so it definitely was not because of the HD textures. I never encountered a single performance issue either so the game as well as the HD textures were well optimized. I definitely recommend both!

There's only two problems that i have with this game. The first one being the random people that you get matched with are not friendly. Most will kick you at the last second before you can get your loot. There are others that hack the game and cause problems or use hacked weapons that break everything and crash you out. The second problem is the balancing in this game is whack. Basically, if you're not a gunzerker, you won't be able to beat anything on the overpower rank 10 missions. The gunzerker is the only one that has the abilities and the stats to beat the end of game end of game content bosses. All the other characters get hopelessly one shotted in most cases which makes it incredibly rigid and sad that you can't just use the character that you want to use. 

Other than those two issues, this game, along with the dlc is still worth playing to this day. I'd suggest getting the pack that has all the games and dlc's included. Just forget that pre sequel and BL3 exist and you're good to go.

"Borderlands 2" is an action role-playing (RPG) shooter developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K Games. The game offers an action-packed open-world experience with first-person shooter mechanics and invites players into the frantic and colourful world of the Borderlands universe.

Open World and Story: The game features a story set on the planet Pandora. Players pursue a mysterious treasure called the Vault and complete various missions in the dangerous world of Pandora.

Character Selection and Customisation: Players choose from different playable characters. Each character belongs to a class with different abilities and can be customised through skill trees.

Crazy Weapons: One of the highlights of the game is the unique and varied weapons. Each weapon can have different properties and effects.

Co-operative Gameplay: The game offers the possibility to play together with friends or other players online. By co-operating, you can fight against enemies and complete missions.

Humorous Style and Humor: "Borderlands 2" stands out with its funny dialogues, absurd characters and humorous narrative. The game's world and characters have a unique humorous style.

Graphics and Style: The game features comic book style graphics using cell shading technology. This style gives the game a unique visual identity.

Community and Reviews: "Borderlands 2" is popular among gamers for its action-packed gameplay, humorous narrative and multiplayer co-operative mode. The game's vast open world and quests draw players in for a long time.

Development and Publisher: Gearbox Software is the developer and 2K Games is the publisher. The game is supported by regular updates and additional content.

Conclusion: "Borderlands 2" combines action-packed shooter gameplay with zany humour and unique weapon designs. With Pandora's world, characters and crazy weapons, the game offers an enjoyable experience that you can play for a long time without getting bored. If you are interested in action RPG shooters, "Borderlands 2" can be an unforgettable experience for you. By checking out the game's community and reviews, you can evaluate whether the game is for you.

[h1]BY FAR ONE OF THE BEST GAMES I HAVE EVER PLAYED.[/h1]

Almost 11 years later, this game is still one of the most entertaining looter-shooters on the market. With its quirky, cel-shaded graphics, expansive and engaging open world, and hordes of delightfully challenging enemies, I can safely say that this game is one of the best games I have played in a long, long time.

[h1]THE STORY:[/h1]
I don't want to give anything away, but I will say that the story is incredible. So far, I've been laughing myself silly at the impressive humor, and thoroughly engaged in all that the world of Pandora has to offer. I'm excited to see where this game will take me. Most of the story progresses through quests and missions, but it flows smoothly from one quest to the other. It is simple enough where you don't have to go back and redo missions if you haven't played in a while, but complex enough to be interesting and engaging.

[h1]THE WORLD:[/h1]

Pandora is a wasteland, but it still feels alive. Enemies lurk around every corner, and they are diverse enough that you feel like you are walking through a hostile ecosystem. Rakks dive at you from the skies, Skags bite at your heels, and Shock Cacti zap you if you hit them too hard. Borderlands 2 is not just going from quest to quest; you are part of a hostile planet that feels vibrant and deadly.

The quests don't feel repetitive or boring; in fact, quite the opposite, as every new quest and mission you take on gives you something new and different to experience. Everything in this game is well-executed. Borderlands 2 doesn't go wrong at all (at least for me). If you are planning on getting this game, I would pick up an additional DLC or two, as it adds a lot to the experience.

Good luck out there, Vault Hunter. I'll see you in hell.

[hr]                                                                                                                                          [/hr]

(TL;DR: Good game with great story and great worldbuilding. Buy it.)

[h1] BORDERLANDS 2 [/h1]
[b] A GAME THAT GOES BEYOND ITS BORDERS [/b]

Borderlands 2, developed by Gearbox Software, is an action game in the FPS genre with its unique graphics.

The first game brought a new breath to the game world by combining different graphics, fps, and RPG elements. With its variety of weapons and shooter looters, Borderlands has become a game that players will enjoy playing single or with friends.
Hyperion company, which is the manufacturer of the weapons in the first game, sends an H-shaped spaceship to that region after hearing that there is a more abundant vault than the riches in Pandora.
The company puts the Handsome Jack in charge, who discovers that he can control the eridium supply of this mineral extraction mission.

Borderlands 2 has completely blown me away with its unique blend of humor, action, and looting. From the moment I stepped into Pandora, I was greeted with a world teeming with vibrant characters, quirky dialogues, and endless possibilities for mayhem.

The art style, a perfect mix of cel-shading and grit, creates a visual experience that's unlike anything else. The world feels alive with its distinctive design and imaginative landscapes, which kept me engaged and excited to explore every nook and cranny.

What truly sets Borderlands 2 apart is its fantastic co-op gameplay. Teaming up with friends to take on enemies, complete quests, and share the spoils of battle added a layer of camaraderie that few other games provide. The diverse range of playable characters with their unique abilities also keeps each playthrough fresh and exciting.

The sheer amount of guns and gear available in the game is mind-boggling. The excitement of discovering a new weapon or piece of equipment that perfectly suits my playstyle never gets old. The randomized loot system ensures that every playthrough offers a different experience, keeping me engaged for countless hours.

The story, filled with unexpected twists and memorable moments, had me hooked from start to finish. The charismatic villains, led by the iconic Handsome Jack, are a joy to hate. The dialogues are witty and often had me laughing out loud, adding a lighthearted touch to the otherwise intense battles.

Borderlands 2 has been a rollercoaster of laughter, action, and unforgettable moments. If you're looking for a game that offers endless entertainment, whether you're exploring solo or with friends, this is an absolute must-play

I know this is borderline sacrilegious, but I just didn't enjoy this game a whole lot, and I don't think I'd recommend it to anyone personally. From a gameplay perspective, it just felt pretty dry and repetitive. Sure, there's a billion guns, but quantity doesn't mean quality and the vast majority of the gunplay is pretty boilerplate. When I did get lucky and found a fun gun, usually a legendary, chances were I'd have to replace it within a couple hours anyway as it became obsolete. Character progression was just fine. Especially in sidequests there's a lot of backtracking and time wasted just running between fast travel points. From a story perspective, I was uninvested and unmotivated. The world didn't really interest me and the areas didn't tickle my fancy. The characters were unlikable and uninteresting, some to a much greater degree, and the writing was annoying to the point where it grated on my nerves. For what it's worth these are just my two cents, but I'll be honest about how I feel

If life had a skill tree, "Borderlands 2" would max out the "Laughs Per Minute" stat. This game is like a rollercoaster built by a mad scientist armed with rocket launchers and a quirky sense of humor. From psychos who seem to have attended the University of Nutty to guns with more personality than my neighbor's cat, it's a wild ride.

I've spent more time deciding which gun to use than I have on important life decisions. Sorry, life, but choosing between a shotgun that shoots explosive hamburgers and a sniper rifle with a sarcastic AI is just too pressing. And don't even get me started on the grenades ‚Äì if I ever need to blow up a bad day, I know where to turn.

But let's talk about the characters. They're like a dysfunctional family picnic where your cousin's a talking robot and your uncle's a shotgun-wielding berserker. Handsome Jack is the villain you love to hate, with a face that only a mother could... nope, not even a mother could love that face. And Claptrap? He's like that one friend who's so awkward you can't help but invite him to every party.

The co-op mode is a mixed bag of hilarity and chaos. Working together is essential, unless you find joy in watching your buddies get launched across the map by an exploding barrel. The loot system is like a box of chocolates ‚Äì you never know if you're gonna get a sweet legendary or a mediocre white pistol that's about as exciting as beige wallpaper.

In short, "Borderlands 2" is a carnival of chaos, a symphony of silliness, and a shooter that packs more comedy than a stand-up show by exploding clowns. If you're looking for a game that doesn't take itself seriously and has more explosive barrels than you can shake a stick at, dive into this loony bin of a shooter. Just remember, it's not pandemonium ‚Äì it's Pandora-monium!

The term "Amazing" can't describe about how I feel about this game. This is one, if not, the greatest game of all time. 

I was introduced to it from a childhood friend of mine, and while most people didn't see the hype and gunplay around it because it was so old, the story alone kept me interested at all times. 

And the grinding. The grinding, while a tedious process, is what makes this a game you can come back to again, and again. You can look for different variations of the rare gun your looking for, different shield and effects for everything, and with there being SIX playable characters, and 2 versions of NG+, this game keeps you occupied at all times. 

Although some of the DLC is weird (story wise) there are some that make it the most memorable experience that you have. Tiny Tinas DND DLC is the bet story i've played so far. 

And while modding this game with a randomized can be tough depending on how many things you have to download, its worth downloading the randomizer so you can shoot grenades out of a gun that defies the laws of physics.

So whenever you can, PLEASE get this game, and play it with friends. It is an amazing story, amazing characters, and truely one of the games to popularize the term "Looter Shooter."

This game taught me the word "replayability", and replayable it is. Over and over again, on multiple consoles, multiple PCs, even handhelds. I played through this game so often on so many devices i completely lost track of how many playthroughs i have at this point.

The only downside of this game is that it's kept at 32 Bits, which means playing it on higher settings and higher FPS, even if you have the hardware to handle it, will lead to frequent crashing. The 3rd party "4GB Patch" tool is pretty much required if you want to play it on good settings and above 60 FPS lol

For the first 2 playthroughs of this game, I didn't like it. I thought it was a terrible FPS, I thought the comedy was annoying, I thought the characters and locations were forgettable and boring.

That was like 120+ hours of gameplay ago
Eventually it just sort of clicked, and I was no longer forcing myself, I actively wanted to play this game.
I don't have a name for this phenomenon, but its like despite my resistance, the characters found a way to hook themselves enough that I like them all, the gameplay became charming, the monotony even became entirely tolerable because I was just flat out having fun.
So even now, with a max level character, and another approaching soon, I still return because this game is an experience you can't get anywhere else, not even within the same franchise. (except maybe the pre-sequel) Borderlands 3 plays so differently, I play these games for different experiences at this point. 

Borderlands 2 is a legendary game, I didn't believe it at first, I even tried to deny it, but it has this uncanny ability to hook you.

The game is generally fun and worth it if you pick it up on sale. I had more fun playing Borderlands 1, and generally liked the aesthetic of Borderlands 1 more than Borderlands 2. The writing has definitely aged, most of the jokes hold up, but I think the general tone doesn't come across as hilarious as it was when this game came out a decade ago. 

The story gets confused about what tone it wants throughout the game, and the pacing is very heavy on the early game and a bit rushed towards the end. It can't decide whether it wants to be ironic, unironic, absurdist, dead pan; it's honestly pretty bipolar. With that being said, nothing about the writing brings you out of the story except for one or two somewhat frustrating moments, and it is significantly better written than pretty much anything written in the last 5-7 years. 

I also think they could have handled the villain better in the first 2/3rds of the game. No spoilers, but you don't really understand the emotional motivations of the villain until well over half way through the game; it would have been more powerful to have these themes present throughout and foreshadow instead of suddenly springing character development twists that don't fit the tone of the scene, or having the player just listen to audio logs in an empty city, or having certain characters just spell things out for you. 

Because this game doesn't really know what tone it wants, it forces certain cut scenes onto you solely for emotional impact. Like a jump scare but for drama. I felt it was implemented in a cheap way due to the game essentially explaining what will happen before it happens, then expecting some emotional response when, yup, the thing we saw coming happened. (There are a few surprises that are handled well) It's ironic that the writers used foreshadowing in this case but struggled to foreshadow information about the villain that would have made the first half of the game more compelling. After completing the game and playing again, you will notice certain things that coincide with some character development you learn later on, but its inclusion adds nothing to the overall story and could have been left out and changed nothing about the game. 


Anyway, the gun-play is great, and some of the most fun you can have in a shooting game. I think the game achieves the perfect balance of weapon verity and complexity. Just enough to keep you interested but not so much that you are wasting tons of time comparing small stat changes between identical weapons. The guns all operate in different ways and the integrated lore of the different weapons manufacturers is an enjoyable touch. It really caters to all play styles, so you'll be satisfied if you want a specific experience. 

The AI is generally challenging enough and straightforward to learn. Enemies are pretty easy to defeat, and the most fun is mowing through hordes of bad guys while making your way to your next checkpoint. By the end game, and in some of the DLC content, there's a bit of a bullet sponge problem with some enemies and bosses. These fights usually consist of mag dumping the enemy while running backwards, getting hit while trying to avoid a charge attack, reload, mag dump, repeat until enemy is dead. The only real deaths I had were environmental; most of the time death was not due to playing poorly or getting outclassed, but rather lack of map knowledge. I will say this game was pretty easy for me. You level and gain power at a fun rate, but I didn't encounter many difficult areas that I struggled to complete, with the hardest aspects of this game being finding your way around to the marked checkpoint.

In general I think this is a game that most people will enjoy. Even with the shortcomings I outlined in my review, I enjoyed playing this game again and wanted to continue playing while going through the story, even though the story itself wasn't very compelling to me.

My Favorite Game Of All Time

Borderlands 2 has cemented itself as a classic in the world of gaming for very good reasons. 

Let‚Äôs start with what i liked about the characters, world and story:

While being able to shake things off with humor, the main characters all have their own writing which makes them stand out and the 2 main examples of this are Tiny Tina and of course handsome Jack. Jack is a deranged man who after constant failure declared himself the sole dictator of pandora. His ultimate goal being wiping out the bandits. At the start of the story his character starts out witty and a bit unserious but after holding back his plans so often you are suddenly able to feel his grudge. and while his goals are gruesome and deranged you kind of grow empathy towards him. These are the signs of an amazing villain and he and the story around him alone are worth it to play the game.

NOW WHAT REALLY MAKES ME A FAN OF THIS GAME IS THE GAMEPLAY LOOP.

Borderlands 2, especially after the addition of OP10 heavily plays with the addictive feeling of progression. Leveling up all the Vault Hunters, getting perfect rolls of weapons and shredding raid bosses with them as a result is something that is addictive and fun but feels so rewarding once you got there. Not only that but the many ways you can play characters, for example Zer0 with a melee, sniper or gun build, adds a lot of replayability. Aside from the obvious these elements are made even more fun with the witty characters and bigger variety in locations compared to the first installment in the series. it even one ups Borderlands 3 in this aspect because BL3 shows you 99% of the ingame location throughout it‚Äôs story while here there are so many locations left to explore once you are finished. That paired with dedicated drops levels up everything about the game, story and gameplay wise.

Fun story, fun FPS gameplay

imo you need to like Borderlands dialogue for it to be a recommendation. I do like Borderlands dialogue, so I had fun, but sometimes it can feel like you‚Äôre mindlessly shooting enemies just to get to the next piece of dialogue.

The problem is the combat. The guns feel awful to use early and midgame. Sometimes you‚Äôll get a new weapon which does a lot more damage, but feels worse to use due to a lower fire rate and jiggly ‚Äústability‚Äù. Also, you fight the same 5 enemies over and over‚Ä¶

The main story feels too long for what they‚Äôre trying to tell. Jack is [spoiler]super distant, and has no memorable henchmen. His motivations are written into the story, but we don‚Äôt see it in Borderlands 2, only in the other (later) games in the franchise.[/spoiler]

Where the game really shines though is its DLC. They‚Äôre each a lot more focused on a single storyline, and don‚Äôt overstay their comedic welcome. It's here the co-op really shines as well. The DLCs don't take themselves as seriously, so you can laugh together at the fun goofiness. I really liked Captain Scarlett‚Äôs Booty (the DLC) and Mr. Torgue‚Äôs DLC, but all of them are really solid.

Interestingly, the combat becomes much more interesting starting at the 3rd playthrough (Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode). Enemy variety increases as you fight a mix of lategame and earlygame enemies scaled to level. You must use slag and think about your build path, which lets lategame weapons feel powerful and satisfying to use.

Doubly interestingly, all the weapons you use in the 3rd playthrough and beyond are ‚Äúnamed‚Äù weapons, which puts into question the legitimacy of the whole looter-shooter concept.

So if you like Borderlands dialogue, you will probably like the game. The combat does get good, but you need to ask yourself if the ~75 hours to get to the 3rd playthough is really worth it.

BL2 is probably one of the best games I have ever played. It's a fantastic looter shooter combined with an absurdly engaging and highly replayed main story (part of the game's progression mechanic) and side quests. Most, if not all, of the characters are well written and intriguing. The main villain, Handsome Jack, easily tops the charts in terms of greatest video game villains of all time which says a lot considering most of his dialogue is received by the main character through audio logs. Additionally, the build variety provided by countless weapons and gear items along with character skills keeps you thinking about your play style and build optimization even though the game itself is mechanically simple. BL2 is almost always on sale for $15 or less nowadays, so buy the game, grab a few friends, and blast some bandits.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)

Borderlands 2 is an absolute masterpiece of a game that combines intense action, irreverent humor, and a captivating world that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Gearbox Software has truly outdone themselves with this sequel, delivering a gaming experience that is nothing short of legendary.

From the moment you step foot on the unpredictable and danger-filled planet of Pandora, you're greeted with a visual feast. The cel-shaded art style gives the game a unique and vibrant look that stands the test of time. The environments range from arid deserts to lush jungles, each meticulously designed to create a world that feels alive and brimming with personality.

But what truly sets Borderlands 2 apart is its cast of characters. Handsome Jack, the charismatic yet sadistic villain, steals the show with his witty and darkly humorous dialogue. The playable Vault Hunters each bring their own distinct flair and abilities, offering a diverse range of playstyles to suit any gamer's preferences. The side characters are equally memorable, delivering hilarious quips and heartwarming moments that make you genuinely care about the world around you.

Gameplay is where Borderlands 2 truly shines. The gunplay is tight and satisfying, with an unprecedented variety of procedurally generated firearms that cater to every playstyle imaginable. Whether you're a fan of shotguns that set enemies ablaze or sniper rifles that deliver critical hits from afar, the game ensures that your arsenal remains fresh and exciting throughout.

Co-op play is a blast, with seamless drop-in/drop-out mechanics that make teaming up with friends an absolute joy. The game scales dynamically based on the number of players, ensuring that the challenge remains engaging and rewarding, no matter how many Vault Hunters you've got by your side.

In terms of content, Borderlands 2 is a treasure trove. The main campaign is a wild ride filled with unexpected twists and epic battles, while the plethora of side quests and DLC expansions provide hours upon hours of additional entertainment. Whether you're hunting down unique loot, participating in hilarious mini-games, or engaging in epic boss battles, there's always something exciting to do in Pandora.

And then there's the humor. Borderlands 2 has an unparalleled wit that consistently delivers laughs, whether it's through clever pop culture references, quirky NPC dialogue, or the absurdity of the game's world. It's a rare gem that manages to balance intense action with lighthearted comedy, creating an experience that is as fun as it is engaging.

In conclusion, Borderlands 2 is a must-play title that stands as a shining example of the best that the gaming industry has to offer. With its captivating world, memorable characters, addictive gameplay, and uproarious humor, it's a game that will have you coming back for more long after you've saved Pandora from the clutches of Handsome Jack. So grab your friends, load up your favorite guns, and get ready for an unforgettable adventure through the chaotic and captivating world of Borderlands 2.

Best in the franchise, but without its flaws. Good gameplay and grind felt nice. Was fun to play back then and still is today. Characters are obnoxious but eh. I don't care tbh. Grinding for weapons is great until you hit Level 30. Won't take long until you get there, but it's a fun short period of just getting guns that look awesome. After that, you need to look into grip styles, stock styles, a bunch of different styles of each part of the weapon that has hidden stats that is never told to you. It's annoying the first time you find out, but it's alright knowing about it getting in. What the styles do in the end is just make grinding for any weapon feel worthless if you don't get all the meta parts. I would normally say "It's alright if you don't care," but I genuinely can't say that. There are a lot of enemies that are extremely spongy, bosses that only ever react to that kinda weapon, and weapons that are mandatory to have with those styles for raids for better legendary gear. It's atrocious, but this is probably the best in the franchise coming second to Pre-Sequel.

PART 1 GOAT
Hidden behind A mask of wackiness this game Is A surprisingly good first person shooter. On par with Dooms level of polish. Honestly, was reminded of
playing the six games of Halo on Legendary from Halo: The Master Chief Collection, obvious GOAT.
PART 2 My History
I have A peculiar history with this game. Before Borderland 2 was released My buddies would talk about this game, I was one of the people who was excited
for Its release and played It some time In 2012 when It came out with my buddies on Xbox 360.
This one guy would host the server, me and him completed the entire Borderlands 2 campaign on Xbox 360 twice and once on Xbox One. Each time we
completed the entire campaign, I would lose my save. Me and this guy were total strangers to each other though other than playing the entirety of 
Borderlands 2 together.
PART 3 Issues
When It came out on Xbox 360 there was A weird freezing issue which I experienced which was frustrating. It's 2023, 11 years after Its release and I suffer a 
similar issue on PC. The game tries to connect you to the internet every couple seconds even If you are In offline mode and It freezes the game doing It. 
On Xbox 360 the fix was to unplug your ethernet cable and plug It back In. On PC It's the same for me, cause I don't have good internet. 
Other than that the game Is smooth, even though It's 32 Bit and DX9. I imagine Borderlands 3 from 2019 Is A GOAT from recent times. Also this game doesn't 
like to alt tab which I guess Is A given since It's A 32 Bit and DX9 game.
PART 4 2012
And this game just reminds me of 2012 In general to be honest. Reminds me of watching season 2 of The Walking Dead TV Show and watching commentaries of
Telltales The Walking Dead on youtube too.
PART 5 Inspirations
This game is obviously inspired by Bioshock It adds Its own flavor with absurdist weapon attachments and highly realistic gun animations. But, Its gameplay design Is like that of A shoot em up. Like Halo's missions, you have A set piece to battle on then you move on to the next one while adhering to the games looter shooter mechanics. Doing inventory, buying equipment, reselling items at the store. Definitely inspired by Bioshock and Halo.

For me personally I will never understand the obsession people have over this game, but regardless, I would still recommend the game and I am sure it can provide at least 10s of hours of decent fun to most people.

For some reason (perhaps the fact I play offline?) Steam says I have 1.3 hours on record. If only for my wife's sanity, I wish that were true.

The actual truth is that I've sunk an ungodly amount of hours into BL2, over multiple gaming platforms and various editions, and yet I'll still return to it once in a while like an addict falling off the wagon. I can't recommend it enough.

I must also tip my hat to a mod called BL2 Fixed , which let's you skip dialogue and cutscenes (it does other stuff too, but you can toggle features to keep the game as vanilla as you wish). For a game designed around replayability, it's damn near essential. 9/10.

I first played this game a month after it released back on PS3, and there's no dispute that Borderlands 2 is fantastic. The vault hunters are amazingly well designed & very fun, the story is pretty good, and the characters are AMAZING. Handsome Jack stands as one of the best villains in video gaming. The gameplay shows a bit of age now, but still stands strong. This game is a masterpiece, and although the other Borderlands games do a lot well in their own rights (Borderlands 3's gameplay is stellar, and 1's atmosphere is amazing), none score as high consistently across the board as Borderlands 2.

The only thing that stops me from playing this game more is the fact that I have experienced everything there is to do. If you are looking for a borderlands game to play and are new to the series, I would absolutely skip pre-sequel, part 3, and wonderlands.  If Borderlands 1 ever got a remake with the ability to sprint and all the new cool items, I would play that for sure.

One thing that bugged me when this game released was the removal of the weapon proficiency feature.  In BL2, i felt as if i did not use certain weapon types simply because I didn't need to, or my hero was better with one type.  The weapon proficiency feature forced me to use every weapon class.  really added to the replay ability.  

Please allow us to skip cut scenes after seeing them for the first time.  I don't anticipate gearbox matching the caliber of their old games in new releases.  that being said, follow suit with other game devs and remake/ remaster BL 1 and 2

Lilith is a baddie, 10/10 amazing game.

Genre:  
-AAA First person looter shooter

Fit for me:  
-Very poor fit, I don't play this type of game frequently

Pros: 
-Very unique, creative aesthetic 
-Tons of guns w/ different attributes
-Several characters make it easy to pick a character that suits your playstyle
-Playing w/ friends enhances the experience

Cons:
-The open world feels quite empty at times
-I never felt like I was selecting a gun that I liked, just whichever gun had the highest stats
-A lot of repetitive uninteresting enemies early on
-A lot of grinding to upgrade your character and weapons 
-Poor driving mechanics w/ in vehicles
-Walking around to find your next objective can feel very tedious and slow
-Need to put in a lot of hours to enjoy the more interesting, dynamic experience

Thoughts:
-So this game is just not for me.  It's always tough to judge a game 8 years after it was released, especially a beloved franchise like Borderlands.  I was told this game was a hilarious, innovative, fps w/ hundreds of cool guns and boatloads of content.  It's possible that all this is true but I don't have it in me to spend enough time to find out.  Early game there were tons of bullet sponges, lots of wondering around aimlessly, and killing a few random baddies here and there. 

Consensus:
-Bottom Shelf Game (Tier 5 and make up 10% of my reviews).  There are about 150k ppl on steam that absolutely adore this game, so if you like looter shooters, then this is probably worth a try.  I personally didn't enjoy my experience, so I will not be recommending this one.

A blast to play with so much replayability. If you're looking to get started in the Borderlands series, this is where I'd recommend you start. This was the game to put Borderlands on the map, and for good reason. While the gameplay is a bit dated (it's genuinely difficult to get back to it after getting so used to Borderlands 3's more polished controls), it still holds up fantastic with its story, humor, variety, challenges, and co-op. Definitely recommend playing it with friends, but it's still just as fun solo.

One of my favorite looter shooters from hours spent on Xbox 360 to PC something I'd recommend to anyone looking for a fun co-op or single player experience!

So, you want to play a fun, potentially co-op, first person shooter game, eh? You've come to the right place! Borderlands 2, also known as the best one in the series, but not my personal favorite. Control 1 of 4-6 vault hunters, each with their own skills and unique abilities. Shoot the hell through tons of robots, psychos and creatures Pandora has to offer. Gather all the guns you can get, and remember the acronym WGBPO, or use my mnemonic device, Wild Gorillas Be Punching Orangutans, also known as the gun rarity. The wilder the color, the better the shoots. So, what are you waiting for? Grab your guns, friends, and take on one of the best video game villains ever created in Borderlands 2.
