Meh, it feels more like a small "ok'ish" expansion than a proper sequel to Borderlands 1.

Barely any difference in its clunky gameplay or cringe meme humour.
Absolutely ZERO improvements on overall game design, UI or quality of life when comparing to Borderlands 1.

Playable characters are barely different than those from Borderlands 1 too (beside two DLC characters of course so you know where Gearbox had their priorities).



The good part about this game? 
Well, let's see:

>The dialogue, story, script and villain are so uninspired and generic that its perfectly fits with blandness of Bordelands 1 so if you did enjoy Borderlands 1 then you will surely enjoy Borderlands 2

>The new vehicles are 100 times more fun to use than in Borderlands 1

>New element "slag" is a pretty interesting idea, allowing you to do a damage combo with differnet guns

>The final boss fight was 100 times better than final boss fight from Borderlands 1, thats for sure

>DLC's are good. At least some of them. Ok, ok, ok fine - only half of them are ok'ish.....



The bad stuff:

>The other half of DLC's

>Quests, characters and areas are even more boring and dull than in Borderlands 1

>Less unique main quests, more grindy copy pasted sidequests designed for just that one unfunny joke. Every. Single. Time

>99% of boss fights are still uninspired and generic

>Not many new enemy types and way too many crappy reskins 

>Even more cringe jokes

>Clap-trap did rank up from a goofy yet funny mascot into annoying garbage NPC that cannot shut up for even a second. Yay, fun!



Oh, you know the game is bad when your favourite part of Borderlands 2 will end up "X" in your inventory so you can easier and way faster clean up all garbage items from it. 

Sadly, developers also obviously rushed this game so much that they didn't even bother to change or improve anything since Borderlands 1. SHAME!

5/10

A fast paced shooter, very fun with multiplayer but also good solo. Different characters have different skill trees and things that they are good at. Because of the stylistic animation it still holds up reasonably well on the graphics end, despite the age of the game. Humour and commentary during the game is meant for a mature audience, so that's the only thing I would flag as far as content advisories. That, and the usual level of blood splatter and violence.

For game play, currency covers most things. You can buy health and bullets from vending machines as well as pick them up from monster drops, and you are charged an amount when you are killed and need to respawn. It's annoying to get killed, but so far it hasn't been a major problem. Most ammo is easy to find if you're willing to open containers and do some basic exploring, so I've rarely found myself ammo starved thus far. As you play, you also unlock character customisation options and collect "badass point" that allow you to tweak your overall build. For example, higher damage with specific weapons, or better shield recharge rates.

It's fun, and cheeky, and plays well with keyboard and mouse (I can't speak for controller), though the vehicle controls took a little getting used to.

Borderlands 2, developed by Gearbox Software, is a thrilling and addictive first-person shooter that takes the looter-shooter genre to new heights. With its engaging gameplay, witty writing, and vast array of weapons, Borderlands 2 offers a wild and unforgettable journey through the chaotic and humor-filled world of Pandora.

One of the standout features of Borderlands 2 is its addictive and satisfying gameplay loop. Players assume the role of one of several unique Vault Hunters, each with their own special abilities and skill trees, as they embark on a quest to defeat the ruthless villain, Handsome Jack. The game seamlessly blends first-person shooting with RPG elements, allowing players to level up, acquire new skills, and customize their characters to suit their preferred playstyle. The wide variety of weapons, from pistols and shotguns to rocket launchers and elemental guns, ensures that combat remains fresh and exciting, as players constantly seek out bigger and better gear to unleash upon their enemies.

Borderlands 2 shines with its captivating and humorous storyline. The writing is witty, filled with memorable characters, and peppered with pop culture references. The charismatic antagonist, Handsome Jack, steals the show with his snarky remarks and villainous charm. The game's engaging narrative, packed with unexpected twists and turns, drives players forward and keeps them invested in the world of Pandora.

Visually, Borderlands 2 stands out with its unique and visually striking art style. The cel-shaded graphics give the game a comic book-like appearance, enhancing the over-the-top action and vibrant environments. The attention to detail in the character designs, weapon models, and environmental textures creates a visually appealing and immersive experience. The world of Pandora feels alive and diverse, with each area offering its own distinct atmosphere and challenges to overcome.

The cooperative multiplayer aspect of Borderlands 2 is a major highlight. Players can team up with friends online or locally, experiencing the chaos and humor of the game together. Cooperative play enhances the gameplay experience, as players can strategize, share loot, and take on challenging quests and raid bosses as a united front. The cooperative mode promotes camaraderie and adds longevity to the game, allowing for endless hours of cooperative fun.

The game's extensive post-launch support, including additional downloadable content and expansions, further extends the gameplay and provides new adventures for players to embark upon. These expansions introduce new areas to explore, formidable enemies to conquer, and unique loot to acquire, ensuring that the world of Borderlands 2 remains fresh and engaging even after completing the main campaign.

In conclusion, Borderlands 2 is a thrilling and addictive looter-shooter that offers an unparalleled blend of action, humor, and character progression. Its engaging gameplay, witty writing, and visually striking art style make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters, RPGs, or simply seeking a wild and humorous gaming experience, Borderlands 2 delivers an unforgettable journey through the chaotic and loot-filled world of Pandora. Strap on your guns, gather your friends, and get ready for an exhilarating adventure you won't want to put down.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead‚Äì murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time ‚Äì something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange ‚Äì uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" ‚Äì on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is

Honest Review 10/10


Weapons:

What truly sets Borderlands 2 apart is its "bazillions" of procedurally generated guns. With a combination of parts, manufacturers, and elemental effects, the game generates an almost endless variety of weaponry. No two guns are exactly the same, keeping the looting experience fresh and exciting throughout your journey.

Tiny Tina DLC:
The visuals in Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep are simply enchanting. The DLC transports players to a vibrant and imaginative land filled with towering castles, mystical forests, and treacherous dungeons. The cel-shaded art style remains true to the Borderlands aesthetic while incorporating a delightful fantasy twist, resulting in a visually stunning and cohesive world that is a joy to explore.

One of the best games to date

A great, immersive game with an amazing soundtrack and story line, RPG/Mad Max inspired FPS.

Re-bought it for PC after playing it initially on Xbox 360, still holds up after all these years, every play through has multiple new things to discover and the dialogue never gets old.

Borderlands 2 def became one of my favorites, even after the pre-sequel and Borderlands 3 were released, something about Borderlands 2 is just special.

Coming from a lifelong console gamer, playing Borderlands 2 on mouse and keyboard was a bit challenging, as my usual FPS technique did not apply, but after a bit, I quickly realized how much better is it to game on mouse and keyboard, this has upped my enjoyment of Borderlands 2 even more.

The music gives you an intense feeling while fighting for your life or the most melancholic melodies while feeling utterly alone while exploring the vast wasteland, prob one of the best soundtracks to any game, I tend to listen to the music even when not gaming to re-visit that wasteland feeling when not gaming.

The graphics are simple yet give it that perfect post-apocalyptic look that more games should consider, they fit Borderlands perfectly.

I have spent countless hours just wondering around and staring at the well crafted worlds, or done the opposite and hunted down a single boss multiple times for the potential loot, there are countless ways to go about it.

Highly recommended if you like multiple styles of genres in one game, even after beating it, new enemies will be available to up the replay value even more.

The game is great, one of my favs among coop titles, 10/10. I used to drop it every time I tried it on reaching something like lvl 15 of normal* playthrough before, however one time I decided to finish it I absolutely didn‚Äôt regret that I gave it a chance. Now I plan on completing it with every character or at least the most of them. 

Even though the game is not boring playing solo, coop is a way much better approach, if you don‚Äôt have friends try to find someone to play with you on discord communities, steam groups, etc‚Ä¶

Information after this sentence may be considered spoiler/gameplay spoiler for someone. Read at your own risk!

If you want to play this game, I‚Äôd like you to consider the following:

	1. This is by far the most important thing. Talking about playthrough I used the word normal*. The game lets you complete main storyline 3 times per created character. There is huge number of side quests including DLCs and you will travel the world a lot completing all these (we will come back to this particular moment later in (2.)). So, what‚Äôs the catch here you may ask? Well, the first normal* playthrough is just the beginning of the actual game. You complete the main story and then you are able to start a new game using your current character jumping from normal* to True Vault Hunter Mode (TVHM from now on). If you decide to give it a try, your normal* progress in normal world is saved (you will be able to come back here later any time you want), your inventory as well as perks and level is kept aswell (so basically it is NG+). What does the TVHM give you? Briefly, more powerful enemies and bigger chance of getting a rare item. After completing main storyline on TVHM once again you will be rewarded with Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode. This is when the REAL game starts. You get even more powerful enemies as well as even bigger chance of getting a rare item. In conclusion, I STRONGLY recommend just speedrunning (not the actual speedrunning but you got me :) ) normal* and TVHM worlds without touching that much of side quests. Again, you will be able to jump on any of the worlds: normal*, TVHM, UVHM and the chances as well as enemies will remain the same as they were before jumping to the next type of world

	2. So, before I said that you will travel a lot and I REALLY meant it. What could help you here? Mods. They also help filling your ammo and healing with 1 button instead of browsing in-game store. It might annoy you. I don‚Äôt know any more things I can add here so I will just leave my recommended essential mods list here:
- Better Spawns And Better Travel ‚Äì allows you to travel from any location that has teleport station it is THE MOST important mod on my opinion. Will save you huge amount of time wasted running around
	- AutoPickup ‚Äì auto picks up syringes, ammo, money and eridium 
	- Bank And Stash Anywhere ‚Äì allows you to open bank and stash from anywhere, useful things to not travel to sanctuary when you find a valuable thingy
	 - Bossbar ‚Äì adds healthbar to important enemies who don‚Äôt already have it
	- First Person Driver ‚Äì nothing to add xd
	- Loot Marker ‚Äì adds map marker to important loot
	- Loot Notificator ‚Äì plays a sound when something valuable has dropped and also leaves particles
	- Mission Quickswitcher ‚Äì I already said that there is a huge number of quests
	- Movement Tech ‚Äì allows you to double jump. I think that the game should have this possibility. It is not OP but movement feels way better with this one
	- PickupAsTrash ‚Äì allows you to pickup items and mark them trash instantly and this feature lets you sell them all with one click later
	- PickupMessage ‚Äì shows a message with the name of item you just picked up. Helpful when you picked up something by accident
	- Unspec Skills ‚Äì even though the game gives you the ability to pay A TINY amount of money for doing this, it may be annoying to reach the customization station each time. It is just a time saver. Just press right click to get the skillpoint back

3.Buy ALL DLCs. They are great. Just trust me. My personal fav is Tiny Tina‚Äôs Assault on Dragonkeep but you should also check the others. Some of them are not that big but there are huge ones

Borderlands 2 is an absolute masterpiece in the looter-shooter genre. Its visually stunning cel-shaded graphics, addictive gameplay, and engaging story make it a must-play. The vast variety of weapons and gear keeps combat fresh and exciting, while the witty writing and memorable characters provide endless entertainment.

Whether playing solo or with friends in cooperative multiplayer, Borderlands 2 offers hours of chaotic fun. The game's enduring quality, even years after its release, is a testament to its exceptional craftsmanship. Prepare for an unforgettable adventure through the vibrant world of Pandora.

10 / 10

I know it only says that I've played this 25 hours at the time of this review, but I had it on Xbox too and probably put a lot more time into this game that I realize. And the reason why is because this is a great game. It's probably one of the better games I have ever played as it keeps me coming back every few years. It's a great shooter, and yes, it still holds up in every way today. Even the stylized graphics make it look good 10 years after it came out. So that's pretty awesome! It's loads of fun for a pretty good price, and definitely worth many replays with all the different characters. If you haven't played this game before, and you like first person shooters, go get "The Handsome Collection" It's worth the money. I'm trying to think of a downside, but this is one of the rare games out there where there really isn't one. It's just a solid game!

Borderlands is Junk Food. 

The kind that will give you diabetes if you eat too much.

The franchise basically wrote the book on how to make a mediocre shooter along the lines of the seventh gen. Everything you need is there. An endless grind list of generic objectives, a boring progression system, gameplay that is a carbon copy of Call of Duty mechanics mixed with a very basic randomized rpg loot system of games like Diablo, timid weapons that seem to be made of cardboard and that the despite having a huge variety, ironically they all look the same, almost non-existent level design. And humor... Haha. Lots of decade-old teen humor written by bearded adults.

"Diablo with guns" called those who had little regard for Diablo and shooters in general.

IT'S ABOUT NUMBERS GOING UP.

That's exactly it. No skill required boys. Just the empty, addictive satisfaction of watching your time evaporate.

And everything is fine. It's a very polished product and the choice to utilize cellshading has made this game age better than any other of its time. If you're looking for an excuse to turn your brain off without learning anything interesting or maybe doing something undemanding while listening to podcasts, or simply have friends with as dubious taste as yours to join you in what is perhaps one of the most canned products of the last decade. Go ahead. It's almost fun.

P.S: And I should warn you that people stupider than me (There aren't many) have complained about Borderlands 3 for some reason. It's the same game, just prettier and the weapons have a bit more impact and genuine variety. It's a better game in every way except... The writing part? Which has always been bad for anyone who has ever come close to a book in their life. The writing and the cartoonish sense of humor was never a high point. It's a brand of "comedy" made by people who think Clap Trap having pictures of bikini robots on the wall is funny. So... go play Boderlands 3 instead of this.

P.S.S: The giant staircase joke is good.

Used to be purples now and again, maybe even an orange if you're lucky.  Now its not even worth looking.  Not even worth selling the items because there's nothing to do with the cash.  I thought maybe if I did the slots enough I'd get somethin, got 1 purple and about 100 greens, and maybe 500 greys and nothins.  I think the game is effectively "holding out on you" because its afraid to give too much and overwhelm you but well... that's what happens when you overcompensate for what you're afraid might happen.  Focus must be not on not compensating, but on creating the perfect balance.  Not on fears, but on love.

Disclaimer: I only write a review once I 100% a game. Additionally, I don't judge graphics and neither should you. Graphics DON'T matter. Proof? Dwarf Fortress, Stardew Valley, Among Us, FTL, HoMM3 and YOU, back in 1998 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• your pants with excitement by playing Quake 3 and Half-Life at 800x600 on 15" CRT monitors.

What can I say about Borderlands 2 that hasn't already been said, written or drawn on Rule 34... Yeah... Especially nine years after the game has been released and Borderlands 3 has been out for a while as well...

Well, it's the archetype of looter shooters, right? You shoot, you loot, you chuckle at some funny reference, rinse and repeat. Fairly mindless, as the entire FPS genre is, but the difference is this one is actually worth a crap. At least for a little while, it does get repetitive eventually.

The story is pretty good and a decent continuation of the first game and the art style is the signature Borderlands feel which is great. It also includes Tiny Tina so that's a win.

I wasn't a fan of the elemental damage system, it simply doesn't work as well as you would expect, but then again, I played primarily as a Sniper Zero so I mostly just one-shot-crit everything, so it might just have been me. Most of the UI works well, but there are certain parts of it that are simply idiotic. Why isn't there a "Fill Ammo" button at the vendor? The "stash" interface is also horrific.

Don't even get me started on compatibility. The game version is 1.8.4 on Linux, 1.8.5 on Mac and 2.0.0 on Windows. Now, I generally would laugh at you if you decide to mainstream game on anything that's not Windows, but how can you half-ass a popular game so much that you don't even have the same versions? That means cross-play between PC platforms is all but impossible (there are workarounds, but not for the latest DLC).

There are too many goddamn DLCs and most of them are garbage. The Tiny Tina one would be amazing if it didn't have the worst enemies in skeleton types and the worst "arena"-type quest. And to be fair, I don't expect that to get any better with future games, considering Gearbox is now partially owned by an umbrella company.

It seems like I bash it a lot, but the main game alone is worth a playthrough and is indeed fun and entertaining. The rest is a questionable money grab, but can be fun, especially if you have someone to play with. But it all comes together in the Handsome Collection for like $10, if not less at this point, which includes the Pre-Sequel, so it's definitely worth a purchase.

I never expected to get into this game as much as I did. I expected to make a casual run with one character and call it a day, yet here I am, 200 hours later on single player.

Interesting enough, the element that a lot of reviews highlight, which is the writing, doesn't gel with my tastes at all. If you consider it to be good writing going through a never-ending stream of jokes where the punchline is always killing or torturing someone, then please guffaw away, but what actually caught my attention was everything else.

It can't be overstated how amazing the artstyle is, and the overall feeling of the world benefits a lot from the comic book aesthetics. There is also an interesting sense of space that is neither one of those endless worlds nor a constrained space, reaching a good balance between both.

The gameplay loop is very tight, and the player always feels compelled to find something to do. Level scaling is not a mechanic I usually appreciate, but here it actually works quite well. Just remember to only accept missions when you are actually going to do them, because the acceptance is what scales the mission, no matter when you complete it.

Combat feels fun and mostly skill-based, weapon variety is of course off the charts, and there is enough reason to both conserve some of your equipment and switch part of it all the time. I guess this kind of synthesizes the main quality of the game: balance.

It is fun enough to run though the campaign multiple times, but what I found to be a blessing on my second run was to simply disable voices and let go of the so-called witty dialogue. The game felt much faster and more interesting to me. Your mileage may vary.

Chocolate Chip Cookies:
1 cup butter, softened
1 cup white sugar
1 cup packed brown sugar
2 eggs
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
1 teaspoon baking soda
2 teaspoons hot water
¬Ω teaspoon salt
3 cups all-purpose flour
2 cups semisweet chocolate chips
1 cup chopped walnuts

Step 1
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Step 2
Cream together the butter, white sugar, and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Dissolve baking soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips, and nuts. Drop by large spoonfuls onto ungreased pans.

Step 3
Bake for about 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are nicely browned.

Enjoy

A fun classic, but it's age shows.

I've done everything possible up to and including OP 10. All of the DLC. All of the re-runs. Multiple consoles. (almost) Every character played. Here are my thoughts.

It's overwhelmingly positive for a reason. It's super fun to shoot the weapons. The enemies are extremely diverse and fun to listen to burning while purpled up becuase the guns can do that. 87 Bazillion guns to play with. And every class is fun to play and have their place in the game.

The elemental system is well built and makes sense. Fire for flesh; Electric for sheilds; Corrosive for metal; Slag is a debuff.
Every gun has a manufacturer attached, which gives every gun a base set of stats and expected behavoir per Brand.
A more "hidden" system are the gun parts, each identifiable and give set buffs and nerfs which make every gun unique.
The classic RPG color rating system (WGBPO) makes every dropped gun's value instantly recognizable at a glance.
Many guns have flavor (red) text which gives them extra unique effects.
Skill tree's are very fun to mess around to drastically affect your gameplay.
Every character has a unique personality and decent enough skills and skill trees.

Every single one of these elements tied together with a great story, plenty of side missions, and arguably the best villain ever to be written in a video game create the all time classic known as Borderlands 2.

It has some wrinkles that show it's age unfortunately. The humor is VERY 2012; modern graphical updates overload the old engine, leading to an unfourtante but livable amount of crashes; the online play is a little unreliable; and some settings outright break the game (physX).

Also the OP level system is pretty bad. It really limits viability of 95% of loadouts and weapons, which grows stale very quickly since you already beat the game 3 times at increasing difficulty to access it. Plus... there's no way back from UVHM.

Borderlands 2 is an absolute masterpiece of mayhem and hilarity. With its addictive loot system, dynamic gameplay, and unforgettable characters, it's a non-stop thrill ride from start to finish. The game's irreverent humor and clever writing keep you engaged, while the diverse range of weapons and skill trees provide endless possibilities for customization and playstyles. The vast open world of Pandora is a visual treat, filled with vibrant environments and memorable locations. Whether playing solo or with friends, Borderlands 2 delivers an unforgettable co-op experience that amplifies the chaos and laughter. Get ready to embark on an epic adventure filled with loot, explosions, and hours of pure gaming bliss. Borderlands 2 is a must-play for any fan of action-packed shooters.

gg

Borderlands 2, developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K Games, is a first-person shooter action role-playing game released in 2012. It is the highly acclaimed sequel to the original Borderlands and is widely regarded as one of the best entries in the series.

One of the standout features of Borderlands 2 is its irreverent and humorous tone. The game's writing and dialogue are filled with witty banter, clever pop culture references, and memorable characters. The charismatic and diverse cast, including the villainous Handsome Jack, brings the world of Pandora to life and keeps players engaged throughout the story.

Speaking of the story, Borderlands 2 delivers an entertaining and engaging narrative. Set in a post-apocalyptic world, players embark on a quest for revenge against the tyrannical Handsome Jack, who rules over Pandora with an iron fist. The story is well-paced and filled with twists and turns, accompanied by memorable missions and side quests that offer hours of enjoyable gameplay.

The gameplay in Borderlands 2 is a satisfying blend of first-person shooting and RPG elements. Players choose from four unique character classes, each with their own special abilities and skill trees, allowing for diverse playstyles and customization options. The loot system is a major highlight, with an overwhelming variety of weapons, shields, and mods to discover. The joy of finding powerful gear and experimenting with different combinations adds a layer of addictive excitement to the gameplay.

Borderlands 2 truly shines in its cooperative multiplayer mode. Playing with friends or online partners enhances the experience, as the game scales the difficulty and loot drops accordingly. The cooperative play promotes teamwork, coordination, and the sharing of loot, resulting in memorable and enjoyable gaming sessions.

Visually, Borderlands 2 features a distinct cel-shaded art style that sets it apart from other games. The colorful and vibrant graphics, combined with the detailed environments and character designs, create a visually appealing and immersive world. The accompanying soundtrack complements the gameplay with its energetic and catchy tunes.

One minor criticism is that the game can become slightly repetitive, especially during extended play sessions. Some players may find themselves engaging in similar types of missions and encounters throughout the game, which could lead to a sense of familiarity and predictability.

Despite this minor drawback, Borderlands 2 is a remarkable game that successfully blends humor, action, and RPG elements into a highly entertaining package. Its engaging story, memorable characters, addictive loot system, and cooperative multiplayer make it a must-play title for fans of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned vault hunter or new to the series, Borderlands 2 offers countless hours of chaotic fun and excitement.

Borderlands 2 - A Chaotic Symphony of Loot, Storytelling, and Memorable Antagonists

Borderlands 2, developed by Gearbox Software, is an exhilarating first-person shooter that combines addictive gameplay, a sprawling open world, and a captivating narrative. With its unique blend of humor, diverse characters, and a mind-boggling amount of loot, Borderlands 2 manages to deliver an unforgettable gaming experience.

At the heart of Borderlands 2 lies its loot system, which is nothing short of a treasure trove for players. From guns that spew fire to shields that regenerate health, the game's extensive arsenal caters to every playstyle imaginable. Each weapon feels distinct and boasts its own set of perks, leading to a never-ending hunt for the perfect gear. The sheer satisfaction of stumbling upon a rare piece of equipment or a legendary weapon cannot be overstated, and the game's loot system keeps players hooked for hours on end.

The reward system in Borderlands 2 is equally addictive. Accomplishing quests and defeating enemies grants experience points, leading to skill points that can be allocated across a diverse skill tree for each character. This allows players to tailor their abilities to suit their preferred playstyle, adding depth and strategy to the gameplay. Additionally, the game offers a robust challenge system, encouraging players to complete certain objectives for unique rewards and bonuses. The sense of progression and constant stream of rewards serve as a powerful driving force, ensuring players are always motivated to push further into the game's wild and dangerous world.

One of the standout features of Borderlands 2 is its exceptional storytelling, propelled by the enigmatic and delightfully malevolent antagonist, Handsome Jack. Jack's charismatic personality and sarcastic wit make him a truly memorable villain. His presence looms large throughout the game, and players are constantly driven to stop his reign of terror. The narrative takes unexpected twists and turns, often subverting expectations and showcasing the game's exceptional writing. The supporting cast of characters, each with their own unique quirks and motivations, further enhances the storytelling experience. From the siren Lilith to the eccentric robot Claptrap, the vibrant characters create a tapestry of personalities that keep players engaged in the unfolding drama.

The world of Pandora, where Borderlands 2 takes place, is a post-apocalyptic wasteland filled with bizarre creatures, bandits, and hidden treasures. The game's art style, a blend of cel-shading and gritty realism, brings this desolate world to life in stunning detail. Each area is intricately designed, featuring diverse landscapes and distinct environments. Exploring the vast expanse of Pandora is a true adventure, as players stumble upon hidden caves, abandoned settlements, and breathtaking vistas. The world-building is masterfully executed, making Pandora feel like a living, breathing entity that demands to be explored.

Furthermore, Borderlands 2 boasts a wealth of exceptional downloadable content (DLC), expanding the game even further. From the hauntingly atmospheric "Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep" to the wacky and hilarious "Torgue's Campaign of Carnage," each DLC offers a unique and memorable experience. These expansions not only introduce new areas and enemies but also deepen the lore and expand upon the main story, giving players countless hours of additional gameplay.

In conclusion, Borderlands 2 stands as a shining example of a well-crafted, immersive gaming experience. Its addictive loot system, rewarding progression, compelling storytelling, and memorable characters make it an absolute gem in the world of first-person shooters. Whether you're a fan of chaotic gunfights or engrossing narratives, Borderlands 2 delivers on all fronts, cementing its place as a modern classic in the gaming industry.

TLDR-
Borderlands 2 arguably the best all around of the borderlands games offering a really fun casual experience with a lot of content to have fun chilling and playing with friends as well as a more dedicated hardcore experience with plenty of late game content that will put your min maxed build and your personal skills to the test

Characters-
All of the characters are quite varied in their individual playstyle ranging from the straight forward commando who throws down a sabre turret to provide support and defense to give you breathing room to shoot to your hearts content on the other side of the spectrum you have the Gunzerker which very basic on the surface dual wielding two guns of your choice as your knowledge of the game and his skills specifically improve provides arguably some of the most variety in how you play the game such as infinite ammo as well as infinite damage when built correctly

Story-
To be honest none of the borderlands games have much in the ways of good story telling there's some fun moments but you definitely aren't gonna replay the game for the story

Looting-
This game offers a nearly infinite amount of variety when it comes to the loot to be aquired as you play through Borderlands 2 the game obviously isn't the greatest at balance due to the sheer amount of gear to be found it has it's top tier guns that leave everything else in the dust but with raid bosses as an exception pretty much every gun can give you a really fun time playing through the game whether it be for a more casual experience or if you're playing one of the many challenge runs the community has thought up over the years

Repeatability-
While the game is already very long if you include expansions with just one playthrough upon defeating the game once you unlock True Vault Hunter mode which is basically NG+ and beating True Vault Hunter mode unlocks Ultimate Vault Hunter mode which is the final playthrough stage of the game although being quite a bit more difficult than the previous two usually requiring a fair amount of skill in utilizing the game's mechanics if you find that even after that you still want more give a different character a try from the start as each character is very different from the next usually offering an entirely different experience from the previous not to mention there's plenty of personal challenges that the game is very accommodating towards

End Game-
Borderlands 2 in my opinion has the best end game content in the entire franchise as it offers a lot of challenge as well as stuff to do in terms of end game for the start after reaching max level it's in your best interest to find the max level variants of your favorite weapons and gear to prepare you for the challenges ahead after making sure all your gear is put together there are arguably two main challenges in the end game of Borderlands 2 Raid Bosses or The Peak the peak is a long gauntlet that as you playthrough will throw pretty much every enemy you've ever encountered in the game not including dlcs generally speaking you're tasked with running through this gauntlet 10 times each time you defeat the gauntlet you go up one overpowered level which is basically another level on top of your max level stacking up to overpowered level 10 and the gauntlets difficulty for the next run through is increased onto raid bosses typically stand out for their name usually containing "The Invincible" for every expansion you get two additional raid bosses to challenge these bosses are generally speaking meant to be fought with a team of four but they are more than possible solo although they will be significantly harder doing so now they are not all created equal in their quality, challenge, or fun fighting some of them can be really fun and rewarding to fight while others are extremely tedious, drawn out, and reward next to nothing (or in the case of Dexiduous literally nothing) for the effort invested in terms of which ones are fun and aren't I can't really say as each person is different in terms of which raids they find fun and/or challenging 

Additional notes-
-The game has a little bit of a modding community there are several overhauls as well as challenge mods to further add replayability and freshness to each playthrough it's unfortunately not as easy to start modding as other games but it's not too bad once you get it down
-This game even after 10 years of existing still has a very active community on both youtube and the game's fan wiki so if you're still unsure watch some people on youtube play through some challenge runs or something they're very entertaining to watch even if you're not a fan of borderlands

If you are not a fan of your single player games connecting to the Internet for no good reason, or if you simply play your games offline for whatever reason, be warned that you will encounter technical difficulties and annoyances with Borderlands 2 on PC (the game will hang up on startup for five minutes, each and every time, while desperately trying to "call home" and it won't let you quit the game by normal means once your play session will be over (I kid you not)).

Thanks, Gearbox.

Solo and offline players, you've now been warned.

Edit: I managed to find a workaround that does the job. One has to go out of one's way in order to downgrade one's game's version. Follow this guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2014284368

I am also recommending disabling the black outlines (visit the BL2 page on PCGamingWiki) and using ReShade with Lumasharpen cranked up to the max. The game graphics really shine, that way. You can look up how to enable the console and push the FOV beyond 110 aswell (which I still find too narrow, while 120 feels great).

Also use those launch options:
-nostartupmovies -NoController -nolauncher

Then, you can go to NexusMods and find yourself a save editor in order to do whatever you still need the game to do, and voil√†, you are all set.

One of the most enjoyable multiplayer, co-op experiences ever. Played it with 3 of my nephews each week and I really looked forward to each week. It took everything that was good about the original and improved on it, except in the player characters. The original player characters were more memorable in the first game; so much that they were the primary NPCs in this one. The other NPCs were so much more memorable though. Great side quests that hardly ever feel routine and repetitive, even though they are, because the whole game is amusingly repetitive. Grabbing ever better guns is what the game is about and is so much fun. Even the dlc didn't disappoint, and I'm not a big fan of most dlc generally. They had hilarious side missions with really funny characters and scenarios. It holds up really well thanks to the comic book style graphics and some references to pop culture over a long time frame.
     The DLC were fun, some not as much as the main game, but others were better. The assault on dragon's keep, specifically, was arguably the best DLC I've played in any game. 
     I'd reroll a character for this before restarting the first again, which says something, because the first one was so much fun as well. They are just great games to relax to with friends.
I love the combat in this series. It just feels so satisfying. The sequel has great jokes and though it is not as groundbreaking as the original, it is more fun.

To be frank, the game was too boring for my tastes, so I did not play it long. I disliked the atmosphere of the game, as it felt like there were too many enemies and not enough genuine interaction. The mobs quickly became repetitive, and the main character I wanted to play as for his class just looked horribly ugly. This detachment between me and the game is ultimately why I have chosen to uninstall it.

They updated the game just to advertise Borderlands 3 in the main menu. There's a giant ad banner and an annoying option on the main menu to buy borderlands 3. They also force you to change your name to support crossplay with Epic. 

The update of course also broke the ability to execute mods, and this game is very grindy sans mods. Some people love to fight the same boss 20 times to get a unique gun. I'd rather just get them as I play through the story. I don't recommend this game unless you enjoy grinding bosses for random drops, or if you have the tolerance to reconfigure the moddability everytime an update breaks it.

I hate this game. The main problem is immediately obvious when I compare BL2 with a game like Diablo 2. When loot drops in Diablo 2 you can tell its value just from the item name. Whether it's something that sells for a good amount of gold, or if it's an interesting socketable, or a sick unique. The categories are clear and you quickly develop an instinct that can quickly decide whether a drop is worth your attention from the name or even color alone. Instead in Borderlands it's all just garbage, you have to sift through waves of containers and then contemplate numbers to see if an item may be worth it. It's so boring and tedious guys, holy crap. The combat is okay, I don't mind it, as a matter of fact I don't really mind the rest of the game. The graphics are good too, it's all there and it's decent. The key issue though is this overwhelmingly demoralizing cycle of shooting a few guys and then having to open a million containers with garbage in them, to see if maybe it's worth replacing your generic gun, that you only have equipped because its numbers are high, with another one. There's just no joy in the process, there is an endless sea of uninteresting loot and loot containers. Combined with the game's weak interface it kills the gameplay for me.
